questions.text: Dark brown amniotic fluid resembling tobacco juice is found in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Dark brown amniotic fluid resembling tobacco juice is seen in intra-uterine death and is caused by the presence of old haemoglobin A.

Related Pearl: Indications of Amniotic Fluid Color

Amniotic fluid colour Inference
Colourless Early pregnancy
Straw yellow  Term pregnancy (exfoliated lanugo, epidermal cells from fetal skin)
Meconium stained (green) Fetal distress (other than breech / transverse)
Golden  Rh incompatibility (excessive hemolysis of fetal RBC, excess bilirubin)
Greenish yellow (saffron) Post maturity
Dark red Concealed accidental hemorrhage (contamination of blood)
Dark brown (tobacco juice) Intrauterine death (presence of old HbA)

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not affected in the mode of injury given below?
questions.solution:
The ulnar nerve (C8 and T1) is not affected in this mode of injury. This image depicts shoulder dystocia, which is a birth injury leading to Erb's palsy (C5 and C6).

Erb's Palsy:

Upper Trunk (C5, C6)damage > Suprascapular nerve, Axillary nerve, Musculocutaneous nerve, Radial nerve.

Caused by: Undue separation of head and neck. E.g. Fall on the shoulder and birth injuries.

Clinical features:

Adduction and medial rotation at the shoulder joint, extension at the elbow joint and pronation at the radioulnar joint. (Policeman's tip hand deformity).

Related Pearl: Erb's and Klumpke's Palsies.

Features Erb's palsy Klumpke's Palsy
Causes

Undue separtion of head and shoulder. Upper plexus root involved. 

Eg.Shoulder dystocia at delivery, motor vehicle accidents

Hyperabduction of shoulder. Lower plexus root involved.

Eg. Difficult breech delivery, Holding on to something (e.g. a branch) during a fall, Cervical rib syndrome, Scalene syndrome
Nerves roots  C5 and C6 C8 and T1
Muscles involved

Deltoid, Supraspinatus - loss of abduction 

Infraspinatus - loss of lateral rotation 

Biceps brachii - loss of flexion and supination 

 All intrinsic muscles of the hand
Position of the upper limb/hand Policeman's tip/Waiter's tip/ Porter's tip position Claw hand
Sensory loss +/- Along the outer aspect of the arm Along the medial border of forearm and hand
ANS signs  Absent

Horner syndrome

questions.text: Identify the thyroid carcinoma type correctly matched with its commonly associated feature:
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option among the given options is: Follicular carcinoma- hematogenous spread.

The distinguishing features of each type of thyroid carcinoma:

Papillary carcinoma:

  • Most common type
  • Orphan Anne eye nucleus
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Metastasis to cervical lymph nodes
  • Best prognosis

Follicular carcinoma:

  • More frequent in areas with dietary iodine deficiency
  • Hematogenous spread to lungs, bone, and liver

Medullary carcinoma:

  • Neuroendocrine tumors derived from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid
  • Secrete calcitonin, in some cases secrete somatostatin, serotonin, and vasoactive intestinal peptide
  • Associated with MEN 2A or 2B
  • Amyloid deposits may be present in the adjacent stroma
  • Multicentric C cell hyperplasia is characteristic of familial cases

Anaplastic carcinoma:

  • Undifferentiated tumours
  • Aggressive local growth
  • Distant metastasis is common
  • Worst prognosis

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

 

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: Which of the following is a structural HIV gene?
questions.solution:
"gag gene" is a structural gene that encodes core forming proteins including core p24 antigen.

HIV-1 is a retrovirus (lentivirus) with 2 separate copies of single stranded RNA (ssRNA).

HIV genome includes 3 structural & 6 nonstructural genes.

  • Structural genes:
    • gag - encodes core forming proteins including core p24 antigen
    • pol - encodes viral Reverse Transcriptase, Integrase & Protease
    • env - encodes envelope proteins gp120 (spike protein binds CD4 & chemokine receptors) & gp 41 (mediates fusion)
  • Non-structural genes:
    • tat (transcriptional activator) - enhances elongation of RNA pol 2 on viral DNA template.
    • nef (negative effector) - Promotes downregulation of surface CD4 and MHC 1 expression, blocks apoptosis & enhances infectivity
    • rev (regulator of viral gene expression)
    • vif (viral infectivity factor)
    • vpr (viral protein R)
    • vpu (viral protein U)

questions.text: Identify the finding in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows velamentous cord insertion, where the umbilical cord is attached to the foetal membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta.

If this part of the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part and above the internal os, the condition is called vasa previa. In this condition, rupture of the membranes leads to vaginal bleeding and foetal exsanguination.

Other options:

  • Battledore placenta – The cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.
  • Circumvallate placenta - The foetal surface of placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery made up of a double fold of amnion and chorion.
  • Succenturiate placenta - One or small lobes of placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with an acute attack of gout after alcohol intake. Identify the underlying mechanism:

choices.text: Impaired biliary excretion of uric acid
Increased urate production from damaged hepatocytes
Reduced renal excretion of uric acid

questions.solution:
Alcohol intake precipitates acute gout by decreasing the renal excretion of uric acid.

Following alcohol intake, alcohol and aldehyde dehydrogenase metabolise ethanol to acetyl CoA and reduce NAD+ to NADH in the process. The increased NADH/NAD+ ratio in turn catalyses the conversion of pyruvate to lactate and causes metabolic acidosis. Lactic acid competes with uric acid for excretion in the renal tubules and leads to hyperuricemia precipitating an attack of acute gout.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused in sickle cell nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Papillary necrosis is seen in sickle cell trait which occurs due to the occlusion of vasa recta in the renal medulla.

There is typical enlargement of the glomeruli due to increased blood flow and GFR secondary to the low partial oxygen and high osmolarity.

Renal lesions seen are membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the below-shown Receiver Operator Characteristic curve shows lowest false positive rate?
questions.solution:
Curve A has the highest sensitivity and the lowest false positive rate among the four.

A receiver operating characteristic curve is obtained by plotting a test's true positive rate (sensitivity) against its false positive rate ( 100- specificity) for different diagnostic cut off points.

The shape of the curve reflects the quality of the test. The better the test, the more it moves to the upper left.

Hence for a good test, sensitivity comes close to 100% on the y-axis, and the false positive rate comes close to 0% on the x-axis.

questions.text: Which of the following processes creates the gradient that drives sodium-glucose co-transport?
questions.solution:
Sodium-glucose co-transport is driven by the electrochemical gradient generated by Na+ - K+ ATPase.

The sodium-potassium ATPase extrudes three sodium out of the cell for every two molecules of potassium transferred inside. This creates a negative intracellular potential and also a sodium ion gradient between extra-cellular and intra-cellular fluid.  These gradients drive the transport of sodium with glucose into the cell.

This type of passive transport that exploits gradients generated by energy requiring processes is called secondary active transport.

questions.text: Sensory supply of larynx below the level of vocal cord is by:
questions.solution:
The sensory supply of larynx below the vocal cords is by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Above the vocal cords, the larynx is supplied by internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of superior laryngeal.

Related Pearl: Nerves of Larynx

questions.text: After intubating a patient for the first time, an intern was asked to confirm that the tube was inserted correctly into the trachea. Which of the following is not a sign of correct endotracheal intubation?

choices.text: Detection of end tidal CO2 by capnography
Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube

questions.solution:
Breath sounds in the epigastrium is a sign of esophageal intubation. Endotracheal intubation is characterized by the absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

Signs to confirm proper endotracheal intubation are:

  • Symmetrical chest rise
  • Presence of equal bilateral breath sounds over the chest
  • Absent breath sounds over the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volume
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation.
  • Normal capnography

The most important and objective method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube is capnography. 

Capnography is a non-invasive method of measurement and graphical display of partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled breath or the end-tidal CO2. It is the most reliable indicator of proper placement of the endotracheal tube (ETT) following intubation. Capnograph is the device used for measurement and capnogram represents the CO2 waveform displayed on the capnograph.

The given image shows the normal waveforms in a capnogram.

 

Esophageal intubation: initial end-tidal CO2 may be detected due to swallowed air but later becomes zero. There would be an absence of breath sounds bilaterally over the chest with the presence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

Capnography in esophageal intubation:

 

If the ETT is inserted too deep, it can lead to endobronchial intubation. If inserted too shallow, it can lead to accidental extubation. Thus, an adequate-sized tube should be placed with its tip midway between the vocal cords and the carina.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: All of the following local anesthetics have a long duration of action, except ______.
questions.solution:
All the given options have a long duration of action except lidocaine, which has an intermediate duration of action.

Lidocaine is a local anesthetic that is widely used wherever an agent with an intermediate duration of action is needed. When given along with epinephrine, lidocaine's action is prolonged because of decreased absorption. 

Tetracaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine are long-acting local anesthetics.

Local anesthetics are agents that cause a reversible loss of sensory/motor paralysis in a restricted area. Clinically, they can be used for:

  • topical - direct application of the aqueous solution to mucous membranes
  • infiltration - direct injection of agent to tissue
  • field block - subcutaneous injection to anesthetize region distal to the injection
  • nerve block - injection directly onto peripheral nerves/ nerve plexus 
  • intravenous (Bier's block) - relies on vasculature to anesthetize nerve trunk and endings
  • spinal - injected into CSF in lumbar space
  • epidural - injected into epidural space 

Related Pearl: Classification of local anesthetics based on duration of action

Short duration of action ( 20-45 minutes):

  • Procaine
  • Chloroprocaine

Intermediate duration ( 60-120 minutes):

  • Lidocaine
  • Mepivacaine
  • Prilocaine

Long duration (400-450 minutes):

  • Tetracaine
  • Bupivacaine
  • Ropivacaine
  • Etidocaine

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

Related Pearl: Classification of Local Anesthetics based on the Potency

  1. Low Potency - Procaine
  2. Intermediate Potency
    • Mepivacaine
    • Prilocaine
    • Chloroprocaine
    • Lidocaine
  3. High Potency
    • Tetracaine
    • Bupivacaine
    • Etidocaine

questions.text: How are hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine synthesized in the body?
questions.solution:
Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine occur principally in collagen and are formed by post-translational modification.

Translation of mRNA results in the formation of peptides with proline and lysine. These residues then undergo post-translational hydroxylation by prolyl and lysyl hydroxylases.

Clinical relevance:

The hydroxylases require Vitamin C as a co-factor. Hence, vitamin C deficiency leads to defective synthesis of collagen and manifests as scurvy with bleeding gums, swollen joints, ecchymoses, increased risk of bone fractures and impaired wound healing.

Other options:

Dietary hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are not incorporated into peptides.

questions.text: A person after having a meal had a sense of fullness and feels that he can no longer eat. Which area of the hypothalamus acts as the centre for the given physiological process?
questions.solution:
The physiological process explained in the question stem is that of satiety. The ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus acts as the centre for satiety.

A centre that reduces the desire for food is known as a satiety centre. These centres are sensitive to blood glucose concentration and cause satiety in hyperglycemic states. The hypothalamic areas that regulate satiety are:

  • Ventromedial nucleus 
  • Arcuate nucleus (also acts as a centre for hunger)
  • Paraventricular nucleus (also regulates oxytocin release and water conservation)

Other options:

Option A: Supraoptic nucleus regulates vasopressin release.

Option B: Medial preoptic area regulates bladder contraction, heart rate and blood pressure.

Option D: Lateral hypothalamic area is responsible for causing thirst and eating. It also stimulates rage and fighting.

Related Pearl: Functions of hypothalamus

  • Ventromedial
    • Satiety
  • Arcuate
    • Either increase or decrease appetite
  • Paraventricular nucleus
    • Oxytocin release
    • Satiety
    • ACTH and beta lipotropin and blood pressure
  • Medial Preoptic and anterior hypothalamus
    • Body temperature regulation -
      Anterior: responds to heat
      Posterior: responds to cold
    • Sweating
  • Supra optic
    • Vasopressin
  • Preoptic
    •  FSH and LH via GRH
  • Anterior hypothalamus
    • Osmoreceptor
  • Lateral hypothalamus
    • Hunger
    • Thirst

 

Related Pearl: Functions of Main Hypothalamic Nuclei

Paraventricular Synthesizes oxytocin

questions.text: Vortex keratopathy can be caused by all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Among the given options only apraclonidine doesn’t cause vortex keratopathy (cornea verticillata). It is a bilateral whorl-like corneal pattern of cream coloured lines.

Netarsudil is a Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitor that is approved for lowering Intraocular pressure in patients with open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension. Cornea verticillata is observed with the use of netarsudil. The incidence is more than 20%. It is usually mild and irreversible and not associated with any significant visual abnormalities.

Other causes of cornea verticillata:

  • Fabry’s disease
  • Amiodarone
  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Indomethacin
  • Phenothiazines 

Cornea verticillata:

questions.text: According to the ACOG, prophylactic administration of antibiotics before delivery is indicated in which of the following conditions?

choices.text: VSD with left to right shunt

questions.solution:
For cardiac diseases, the ACOG recommendations are in line with the AHA guidelines on antibiotic prophylaxis and antibiotics are recommended if the patient has a past history of infective endocarditis.

Other options:

  • Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended in cyanotic heart diseases and not in acyanotic shunts. Therefore, prophylactic antibiotics are given only in VSD with right to left shunt.
  • Antibiotics are given if valvulopathy is present after cardiac transplantation.

Related Pearl: Cardiac conditions requiring antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis

High risk cardiac conditions for development of Infective endocarditis and require antibiotic prophylaxis are:

  • Prosthetic valves
  • History of infective endocarditis
  • Few congenital heart diseases which include:
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD, including palliative shunts and conduit
    • Completely repaired congenital heart defect with prosthetic material or device, whether placed by surgery or by catheter intervention, during the first 6 months after the procedure
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects at the site or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
  • Cardiac transplantation recipients with cardiac valvular disease

questions.text: Which of the following glycoprotein is involved in specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor?
questions.solution:
Specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor is by the envelope glycoprotein gp120. But, for infection to take place, cell fusion has to occur, which is brought about by transmembrane gp41.

  • Binding to CD4 receptor requires the participation of a co-receptor CXCR 4 for T cell tropic HIV strains and CCR 5 for macrophage-tropic strains.

questions.text: Which of the following pathogen is shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia which is in the shape of tennis racket or “Heart-shaped” or “pyriform shaped”.

It is bilaterally symmetrical and possesses:

  • Nuclei - 1 Pair
  • Flagella - 4 Pairs
  • Blepharoplast/Basal bodies from which flagella arises - 4 Pairs
  • Axostyles running along the midline - 1 Pair
  • Parabasal or median bodies - 2

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the Bandl ring seen?
questions.solution:
Bandl ring is a pathological retraction ring seen in obstructed labour.

Bandl ring/Retraction ring

  • In obstructed labour, the upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigorously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates.
  • With each contraction, there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner.
  • The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring/Bandl ring.

Other options:

Constriction ring/Schroeder's ring

  • It is formed due to incoordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus.
  • It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes.

Related Pearl: Constriction ring v/s retraction ring in uterus

  Constriction / Schroeder's ring  Retraction/ Bandl's ring
Nature Due to incoordinate uterine contraction Due to tonic uterine contractions and retractions
Cause Undue irritability of uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin Obstructed labor
Location

Usually at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Location does not alter once formed.

Always at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Progressively moves upwards after formed.
Per abdomen Ring not felt Ring is felt
Per Vaginal Ring is felt Ring not felt

questions.text: The risk of genetic diseases in non-consanguineous marriage is?
questions.solution:
The risk of genetic diseases in non-consanguineous marriage is 2-4%.

The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is 4-8%.

questions.text: Hypotension and hypokalemia with marked hypomagnesemia is seen in ______
questions.solution:
Hypotension and hypokalemia with marked hypomagnesemia are seen in Gitelman's syndrome.

Gitelman's syndrome is due to a mutation of Na+-Cl- cotransporter in the distal tubule. The features include metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, normal to low BP, increased levels of renin and aldosterone and hypocalciuria- no renal stones.

Other options:

Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency due to acquired lesions of the adrenal cortex, which prevent the production of cortisol and, often, aldosterone. Hence, due to mineralocorticoid deficiency, there will be hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension.

Addison’s disease is characterized by the following:

  • Hyponatremia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypotension
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Increased adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) levels
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Hyperpigmentation

Liddle’s syndrome is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder that causes increased activation of ENaC channels in the principal cells of collecting duct in the nephron. This causes increased reabsorption of Na exchanged for K+ causing hypokalemia. Increased Na absorption leads to hypertension.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: What is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image above represents the Bragg-peak effect of a proton.

The Bragg peak effect is pronounced for protons. Proton therapy, therefore, allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

Protons and the Bragg peak effect:

The Bragg curve plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter.

The proton is a heavy and charged particle that gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. The proton is very fast when it enters the patient’s body and deposits only a small dose on its way. The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when the proton is ultimately stopped. This is known as the Bragg peak. 

Other options:

Option A: The BOLD (blood oxygen level dependent) effect forms the basis for functional MRI (fMRI).

Option B: The Bohr effect is the loss of affinity for O2 with decreasing pH. It occurs in the microcirculation as oxygen is consumed and CO2 (carbonic acid) is released by tissues.

Option D: The Haldane effect is the phenomenon whereby increasing arterial PO2 reduces the ability of the blood to store CO2 (as Hb-bound, carbamino Hb; or as HCO3-), thereby increasing the CO2 partial pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of catatonia?
questions.solution:
Coprolalia is not a feature of catatonia. It refers to shouting or speaking socially unacceptable or obscene words and is seen in Tourette’s disorder.

The clinical features of catatonia include:

  • Grimacing - making faces (for instance, exaggerated lip-puckering)
  • Mutism - the patient doesn’t speak or speaks very little
  • Echolalia - the patient repeats a word/phrase immediately after hearing it
  • Echopraxia - the patient mimics an observed movement
  • Stupor - absent psychomotor activity
  • Wavy flexibility - little but uniform resistance is offered to passive positioning
  • Catalepsy - a passively inducted posture that is against gravity is maintained by the patient
  • Posturing - the patient spontaneously reaches and maintains a posture against gravity
  • Mannerism - Purposeful movements that look odd, and often exaggerated (for example, repetitively running a hand through the hair)
  • Stereotypy - Purposeless repetitive movements (hand flapping)
  • Agitation - without any causative stimuli
  • Negativism - opposition or no response to verbal instructions or external stimuli

The presence of three or more of these features is required for a diagnosis of catatonia.

questions.text: Wernicke’s area in the brain is located in?
questions.solution:
Wernicke’s area in the brain is located in Superior temporal gyrus.

Cortices of auditory pathway:

Broca’s area:

  • Dominant inferior frontal gyrus (usually left)
  • Brodmann 44,45
  • Function: motor speech area

Wernicke’s area:

  • Dominant superior temporal gyrus (usually left)
  • Brodmann 22
  • Function: Word recall (cognition)

Heschl's gyri:

  • Contains primary auditory area
  • 2 transverse temporal gyrus (part of superior temporal gyrus extending towards medial geniculate body)
  • Brodmann 41,42
  • Buried within the lateral sulcus (sylvian fissure)
  • Process incoming auditory information
  • Deafness with bilateral destruction

questions.text: Encopresis is classified under which of the following categories?
questions.solution:
According to DSM-V, encopresis and enuresis belong to the category of elimination disorders. Encopresis refers to repeated defecation into inappropriate places and is not diagnosed until 4 years of age. It is typically seen in children who withhold defecation which then leads on to overflow of feces and soiling.

Enuresis refers to repeated urination into bed or clothes. It is not diagnosed until 5 years of age.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause opening of the eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
Tensor tympani does not open the eustachian tube.

Muscles of the Eustachian tube:

Muscle Nerve supply Action
Tensor veli palatine/ Dilator tubae Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve Opens the tube
Levator veli palatine Pharyngeal plexus (cranial XI through X) Opens & lifts the tube
Salpingopharyngeus Pharyngeal plexus (cranial XI through X) Opens the tube

Sensory & parasympathetic supply to ET: Glossopharyngeal Nerve

questions.text: Identify the finding marked in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows hemorrhagic spots with pale white centers indicative of Roth spots. The pale centers are composed of coagulated fibrin, platelets, necrotic cells, inflammatory infiltrates, infectious organisms, and neoplastic cells.

These spots are seen in:

  1. Leukemia
  2. Diabetes
  3. Subacute bacterial endocarditis/ Bacteremia
  4. Hypertensive retinopathy
  5. HIV retinopathy
  6. Systemic lupus erythematosus

Other options:

Option A: Bull’s eye maculopathy is seen in congenital cone dystrophy and in chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine toxicity.

Option B: Sunburst spots are foci of clumped retinal pigment epithelium that develop in response to retinal haemorrhage. This finding is seen in sickle cell retinopathy.

Option D: Forster Fuchs spot is a raised circular pigmented scar at the macula seen after resorption of subretinal haemorrhage. It is seen in pathological myopia.

questions.text: The finding shown in the image below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image shows blue sclera which is seen in Marfan syndrome. Here, the blue tinge is due to the uveal pigment shining through a thin sclera.

Other conditions associated with blue sclera include:

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta – Type I and type IIA
  • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome – Type VI
  • Congenital glaucoma
  • Healed scleritis
  • High myopia
  • Pseudoxanthoma elasticum
  • Nevus of Ota

questions.text: Which of the following is a serotonin reuptake enhancer?
questions.solution:
Tianeptine acts by enhancing the serotonin reuptake i.e action are opposite to that of SSRI.

Other options:

  • Venlafaxine: is a serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor
  • Trazodone: is a serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor
  • Amoxapine: is a tricyclic antidepressant

questions.text: The definition of XDR-TB includes resistance to all of the following except:
questions.solution:
XDR-TB does not include resistance to ethambutol.

Definition of XDR-TB:

Extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB), is a form of TB which is resistant to at least four of the core anti-TB drugs. XDR-TB involves resistance to, isoniazid and rifampicin, in addition to resistance to any of the fluoroquinolones (such as levofloxacin or moxifloxacin) and to at least one of the three injectable second-line drugs (amikacin, capreomycin or kanamycin).

questions.text: For a primigravida, what is the definition of arrest of dilation in the active phase of labour?
questions.solution:
Secondary arrest of dilation in the active phase of labour is defined as no dilation for more than 2 hours in both nulliparas and multiparas.

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

questions.text: Which among the following is the safety muscle of tongue?
questions.solution:
Genioglossus brings about the forward traction of the tongue to protrude its apex from the mouth. Hence, it is also called the safety muscle of the tongue.

Acting bilaterally, the two muscles depress the central part of the tongue, making it concave from side to side. Acting unilaterally, the tongue diverges to the opposite side.

questions.text: A college-going student was brought to the ER after suffering a head injury in the college sports event. The 2nd year PG tells you to calculate GCS as you were the only intern available. On examination, you find out that the student was confused, he opens his eyes spontaneously, flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. You calculate the Glasgow Coma Score to be________
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Coma Score in this patient is 13.

To calculate the GCS score, the following clinical points have to be considered:

  • The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused
  • The score for eye-opening: 4, because his eyes are opening spontaneously.
  • The score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+4+5) = 13.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A patient complains of a foamy discharge from both eyes for two weeks associated with irritation and discomfort. The patient’s left eye is shown in the image below. How is this condition treated?
questions.solution:
The image and the history suggest angular conjunctivitis and the condition is treated using topical tetracycline.

Angular conjunctivitis is caused typically by Moraxella lacunata and Staphylococcus aureus (rare cause).

The nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis are the usual sources of infection. It spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs.

It is characterized by the inflammation and reddening of the inner and outer canthi with the excoriation of the skin. There is a collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles. There is discomfort and irritation of the eyes. Tetracycline ointment is used in management.

questions.text: Powder burn spots over the pelvic viscera are seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Powder burn spots over the pelvic viscera are seen in pelvic endometriosis. These are small black dots typically seen on the uterosacral ligaments and the pouch of Douglas. They are surrounded by areas of fibrosis.

Powder burn spots have ectopic endometrial tissue but are thought to be less active than other lesions seen in endometriosis such as red flame-shaped areas, red polypoid areas, yellow-brown patches, white peritoneal areas, circular peritoneal defects and sub-ovarian adhesions.

questions.text: Floaters seen in synchysis scintillans are made up of?
questions.solution: Synchysis scintillans is a degenerative condition seen after trauma or inflammation and is characterised by the deposition of cholesterol crystals in liquefied vitreous. The crystals are also deposited in the anterior chamber and the subretinal space. At rest, they settle down due to gravity but glitter when thrown up by eye movements. No treatment is indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following condition presents with external rotation, flexion and abduction of the leg?
questions.solution:
Typical appearance of hip flexion and abduction is seen in anterior hip dislocations.

In other conditions:

Posterior hip dislocations - flexion, adduction and internal rotation.

Central dislocation - shortening of the limb.

Fracture neck of femur - minimal external rotation of the limb with or without shortening.

  • Femoral head appears larger than normal

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the image given below?

choices.text: It is also known as thiersch graft
Only dressing is enough at donor site
Donor site can be reused before healing

questions.solution:
The image given depicts the harvesting of a split skin graft. The donor site can not be reused before healing.

The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or electric dermatome.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • The presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is contraindicated in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donor to full thickness defect.

Skin grafts can be broadly divided into two categories:

Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts. Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. More dermis in the full-thickness skin graft translates into more primary contraction and less secondary contraction.

 

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post-graft contraction
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions show “Maltese cross” appearance of urinary casts under polarized light?
questions.solution:
Urine analysis in Fabry’s disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a "Maltese cross” appearance. It can also be seen in nephrotic syndrome.

Interpretation of casts in urine:

  • Hyaline casts: Physiological, concentrated urine, fever, exercise
  • Red blood cell casts: Glomerular causes
  • White blood cells casts: Pyelonephritis, interstitial nephritis
  • Muddy brown casts: Acute tubular necrosis, interstitial nephritis
  • Fatty casts: Heavy proteinuria
  • Broad casts: Chronic renal failure

Maltese cross appearance elsewhere:

  • Short-range shotgun wound
  • Babesiosis

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: The F508del mutation in cystic fibrosis is an example of which of the following categories of CFTR mutation?
questions.solution:
CFTR mutations that disrupt protein maturation are termed class II defects and are by far the most common genetic abnormalities seen in cystic fibrosis.

CFT encoding F508del retains partial ion channel function, but protein maturation is arrested in the endoplasmic reticulum.

There are 6 classes of defects involving the CFTR gene:

Class Defect
Class I Absence of synthesis e.g., W1282X, G542X
Class II Defective protein maturation and premature degradation e.g., F508 deletion
Class III Disordered gating/regulation e.g., G551D mutation
Class IV Defective conductance through the ion channel pore
Class V Promoter or splicing abnormality leading to reduced CFTR transcripts
Class VI Accelerated turnover from the cell surface

questions.text: An elderly male came with complaints of severe pain over the metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe. The pain begins at night following the consumption of alcohol. Synovial fluid aspirate showed the following crystals under polarised light microscopy as shown below. What does the image show?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an elderly male with pain in the metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe precipitated by alcohol intake and the image is highly suggestive of gout. The polarized light microscopy image shows negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals.

Gout is a metabolic disease that is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue.

It is more common in males. It is precipitated by alcohol intake, purine-rich food, diuretic therapy, trauma, and medical conditions such as heart failure and hypoxia.

It usually presents as monoarthritis that may be acute and episodic or chronic. Acute gout presents with a joint that is red, hot, swollen, and extremely tender on examination. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the most frequently involved joint.

The image given below shows clinical findings seen in gout:

 

Synovial fluid analysis of joint aspirate is diagnostic and shows the following features:

  • Increased leukocyte count with a neutrophilic predominance
  • Negatively birefringent crystals on polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid.

Radiographic features may be appreciable in advanced gout which includes Martel's sign also known as the G sign, or rat-bite erosion. It refers to the punched-out lytic lesion and overhanging margin of the new bone along the edge of erosion seen in chronic tophaceous gout.

Acute gout can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), colchicine, and corticosteroids while urate-lowering therapy is useful in chronic gout.

questions.text: A patient on haloperidol complains of feeling restless and irritable with an irresistible urge to move. Which of the following drugs is used in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The feeling of restlessness and irritability with an irresistible urge to move is called akathisia and propranolol is one of the drugs used to treat this condition.

Akathisia is an extrapyramidal side-effect of antipsychotics and usually manifests hours to days after initiating antipsychotic therapy or after an increase in dose. Treatment involves the reduction of the antipsychotic dose, administration of propranolol, benzodiazepines or drugs with anticholinergic action like benztropine or diphenhydramine.

questions.text: Melioidosis is caused by which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Melioidosis is an infectious disease caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei.

  • The organism is found in soil and water and is perhaps the most virulent of the Pseudomonads.
  • Melioidosis is similar to glanders disease, which is passed to humans from infected domestic animals.
  • Signs and symptoms may include pain in chest, bones, or joints; cough; skin ulcers; lung nodules; and pneumonia (mainly upper lobe infiltrates).
  • Treatment: ceftazidime or meropenem for 2 weeks.
  • Burkholderia mallei causes the disease glanders.
  • Burkholderia cepacia causes the cepacia syndrome, a rapidly fatal septicemia in cystic fibrosis patients.

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive woman presents with sudden, violent, uncontrollable flailing movements of her left proximal upper limb for the past one week. A lesion in which of the following structure is most commonly found in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given movement disorder describes hemiballismus and the lesion in subthalamus is most commonly found in this condition. 

Hemiballismus is a violent form of choreiform movement where wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements are seen affecting one side of the body. It mainly affects the proximal muscles and can be confined to one limb or both upper and lower limbs.

It is commonly seen in partial lesions i.e, infarct or haemorrhage in the subthalamic nucleus. Thalamus, putamen, and parietal cortex are less commonly involved.

This movement disorder is usually self-limiting and tends to resolve spontaneously after weeks or months. Dopamine antagonistic agents can be given to manage it as well. 

Other options:

Option B: A lesion in the putamen can give rise to chorea. This is described as flicking movements of the hands, face, or any other part of the body.

Option C: A lesion in the globus pallidus can give rise to athetosis. This involves spontaneous and continuous writhing movements of the hand, arm, neck, or face.

Option D: A lesion in the caudate nucleus would hamper cognitive control of motor activity, that is, voluntary movements generated due to the thoughts in a person's mind.

Related Pearl: Site of Lesion of Movement Disorders

questions.text: The structure marked in the diagram given below will supply _________
questions.solution:
The above image shows spinal accessory nerve.

Muscle innervation: It supplies trapezius and the sternocleidomastoid.

Course: Spinal accessory nerve enters the posterior triangle passing deep to the sternocleidomastoid muscle and runs in an oblique direction within the triangle to supply Trapezius.

questions.text: Which of the following promotes gastric emptying?
questions.solution:
Gastrin is secreted by G cells in the gastric antrum and promotes gastric emptying. It has mild to moderate stimulatory effects on the motor functions of the body of the stomach and also enhances the activity of the pyloric pump.

questions.text: Tildrakizumab targets:
questions.solution:
Tildrakizumab is a monoclonal antibody directed against p19 subunit of IL-23 that prevents interaction of IL-23 with its receptors.

Tildrakizumab is indicated in moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis.

IL-23 is a naturally occurring cytokine that is involved in inflammatory and immune responses.

Other options:

  • Reslizumab is a monoclonal antibody against interleukin 5 that in approved for use in asthma.
  • Human IL-1 Receptor Antagonist: Anakinra – is used for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Secukinumab, ixekizumab, brodalumab are monoclonal antibodies directed against IL-17A and indicated in moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis.

questions.text: Romana’s sign is seen in infection with which of the following pathogen?
questions.solution:
Inoculation of the parasite T. cruzi in conjunctiva causes unilateral, painless oedema of periocular tissues in the eye, as shown in the image below, called as Romana’s sign.

  • This is classically seen in acute Chagas disease.
  • Acute Chagas disease occurs soon after infection and may last for 1 to 4 months.

Some additional points:

  • Chagoma is a typical lesion occurring in acute chagas disease at the site of inoculation.
  • Chronic chagas disease is characterized by Mega oesophagus, Mega colon and Myopathy (MMM).

 

Note:

Trypanosoma rangeli is nonpathogenic.

questions.text: Identify the period during which twinning results in the type of gestation shown below:
questions.solution:
The image shows monochorionic monoamniotic twin gestation which is seen with twinning between the 9th and 12th  day after fertilisation.

Monozygotic twinning:

Time of division Type of twin
0-72 hours Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA)

questions.text: What is the most common symptom of genital tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Infertility is the most common symptom of genital tuberculosis. It can also cause other symptoms such as dyspareunia, menstrual irregularities and lower abdominal pain associated with chronic pelvic inflammatory disease.

Genital Tuberculosis:

  • Almost always a secondary infection.
  • Most common route of spread is hematogenous.
  • Most common site is bilateral fallopian tubes (most common part affected is ampulla and most common pathology encountered is endosalpingitis).
  • Most common in 20-30 years age group.
  • Infertility is the most common symptom.

questions.text: What happens when the left eye is covered by an occluder in esophoria?
questions.solution:
The covered left eye moves inwards in esophoria. This is because fusion is lost when one eye is covered and the latent squint becomes manifest. The eye returns to its original position once the occluder is removed.

Related Pearl: Cover tests in ophthalmology

Cover–uncover test:

  • To detect the presence of heterophoria: Latent squint
  • One eye is covered with the occluder, and the other eye is made to fix an object.
  • In the presence of heterophoria, the eye under the cover will deviate.
  • When the cover is removed, the eye under the cover will return back to its normal.
  • This movement is observed.
  • The direction of movement determines the type of heterophoria.

Direct Cover test:

  • Confirms the presence of manifest squint.
  • Differentiates apparent squint from a manifest squint.
  • The patient is asked to fixate on the point light.
  • The normal-looking eye is covered.
  • In manifest squint, the uncovered eye will move in the opposite direction to take fixation.
  • In apparent squint, there will be no movement of the uncovered eye.

Alternate cover test:

  • In the below image, the patient has right exotropia with left eye fixating.
  • Both eyes move each time the cover alternates from one eye to the other.
  • It reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate.
  • It differentiates between concomitant and paralytic squint.

questions.text: Which of the following keratins is expressed in the layer marked as 'D' in the given image?
questions.solution:
The layer marked as 'D' is stratum basale. Keratin 5 and keratin 14 are the major keratins in stratum basale.

Keratin 1, 6 and 10 are suprabasal keratins:

  • Keratin 1 and 10 are the major keratins in stratum spinosum and are characteristic of epidermal differentiation.
  • Keratin 6 (along with K16 and K17) is expressed in epidermal hyperproliferation, as in wound healing and psoriasis.

Autosomal dominant mutations in genes encoding keratin 5 and 14 (KRT5 or KRT14) lead to localized epidermolysis bullosa simplex (most common EB subtype).

Mutations in KRT1 and KRT10 result in epidermolytic ichthyosis.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not expect on administering etomidate to a patient?
questions.solution:
Etomidate does not cause hemodynamic instability due to the lack of influence on the sympathetic nervous system and on baroreceptor functions. Due to this characteristic, etomidate is a useful anesthetic agent for patients with poor cardiac function and/or hemorrhagic shock. 

Etomidate is an intravenous anesthetic agent. Etomidate depresses the reticular activating system and mimics the inhibitory effects of GABA. It has a rapid onset with a shorter duration of action. 

Adverse effects include post-operative nausea and vomiting, myoclonus, pain at the injection site, and transient acute adrenal insufficiency.

Option A: Adrenocortical suppression is caused by inhibition of the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase resulting in decreased biosynthesis of cortisol.

Option C: Thrombophlebitis, a side effect of etomidate, may be avoided by the use of the anesthetic's lipid formulation.

Option D: The incidence of myoclonus may be reduced by premedication with a hypnotic agent such as midazolam.

questions.text: The most common primary procedure performed for bariatric surgery is:
questions.solution:
Sleeve gastrectomy has become the most common primary procedure for bariatric surgery.

A vertical sleeve is created, resecting most of the greater curvature
↓ 
Restriction of stomach capacity
↓ 
Early satiety
↓ 
Reduced consumption of food
↓ 
Weight loss

Advantages of sleeve gastrectomy:

  • Less challenging procedure
  • Preservation of pylorus (avoids gastric dumping)
  • No need of serial adjustments (as seen with gastric banding)
  • Reduction in internal hernias (as seen with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass)  

Complications of sleeve gastrectomy:

  • Bleed from the staple line
  • Leakage from staple line (close to the angle of His)

questions.text: With regard to positioning of the vacuum cups, which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Positioning at flexion point prevents flexion of foetal head
Positioning near anterior fontanelle extends foetal spine
Placement at flexion point maximises traction

questions.solution:
Positioning the vacuum cup over the flexion point allows flexion and prevents twisting of the foetal head. The fixation point is located on the sagittal suture 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle and 6 cm away from the anterior fontanelle. The vacuum cup is placed over this point due to the following advantages:

  • Maximum traction
  • Minimum cup detachment
  • Prevents twisting of the foetal head
  • Delivers the smallest head diameter through the pelvic outlet
  • Improved success rates
  • Lowers foetal scalp injury rates
  • Lessens perineal trauma

Other options:

  • Placement anterior to the fixation point leads to foetal cervical spine extension
  • Asymmetrical placement with relation to the sagittal suture may worsen asynclitism

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in eliciting tickle and itch sensations?
questions.solution:
Itch and tickle sensations are elicited by the stimulation of free nerve endings of unmyelinated type C nerve fibers.

The free nerve ends are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors and are present only in the superficial layers of the skin. After these fibers synapse in the spinal cord, the sensations are carried in the contralateral anterolateral spinothalamic tract.

The same type-C fibers are also involved in carrying sensations of slow pain. The itch sensation calls attention to mild surface stimuli such as a flea crawling on the skin or a fly about to bite. These signals later activate the scratch reflex. This way by scratching one gets relieved of the itch. Sometimes, this scratching action can be strong enough to elicit pain. These pain signals suppress the itch signals in the cord by lateral inhibition. 

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

questions.text: Glass holding cast is applied for the fracture of which carpal bone shown below?
questions.solution:
The carpal bone marked as 1 is scaphoid. Glass holding cast is applied for scaphoid fracture.

Undisplaced fractures of the scaphoid are treated in plaster.  The cast is applied from the upper forearm to just short of the metacarpo-phalangeal joints of the fingers, but incorporating the proximal phalanx of the thumb. The wrist is held dorsiflexed and the thumb forwards in the ‘glass-holding’ position. It is retained for 8 weeks.

questions.text: Average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if current patterns of mortality and disability continue to apply is given by:
questions.solution:
DFLE is Disability-free life expectancy.

DFLE is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if current patterns of mortality and disability continue to apply.

Other options:

DALY is Disability adjusted life years. It combines years of lost life (YLL) and years lost to disability (YLD).

QALY is Quality adjusted life years. 1 QALY = 1 year of life lived in perfect health.

HALE is Health adjusted life expectancy. It is based on life expectancy at birth but includes an adjustment for time spent in poor health.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image below is used to ____________
questions.solution:
The image shows a pachymeter used to measure corneal thickness. The corneal thickness indirectly reflects endothelial function. Ultrasonic pachymeters are more reliable than optical pachymeters.

Indications of pachymetry include the following:

  • Assessment of corneal thickness before and after refractive surgery
  • Monitoring keratoconus and thickness of transplanted corneas
  • Assess corneal edema

questions.text: According to the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India,a state with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  are in:
questions.solution:
States with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  are classified as category-1 which is named as Elimination phase.

The annual parasite Index is calculated as (Cases in one year ×1000) / Population under surveillance. It is used in classifying states/UTs in the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India.

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

questions.text: A primigravida underwent a quadruple screening test at 16 weeks of gestation. All the parameters were low except for serum inhibin A level which was normal. Identify the condition in which the findings given above are seen.
questions.solution:
All the parameters like maternal serum alfa-fetoprotein (MSAFP), beta HCG, and unconjugated estriol levels are reduced in trisomy 18/Edwards syndrome. Maternal serum inhibin A level may be normal or reduced.

Quadruple testing is usually done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. This test can additionally help in picking up Smith-Lemli-Optiz syndrome. However, one of the limitations of the test is that it fails to detect trisomy 13. 

In trisomy 21 and neural tube defects, the changes in the screening markers are as follows:

Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows:

Dual test (1st trimester) Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test (2nd trimester)
Beta HCG  Beta HCG  Beta HCG 
PAPP-A  Unconjugated estriol  Unconjugated estriol 
This can be combined with nuchal translucency by USG MSAFP  MSAFP

questions.text: Which of the following is not an anaphylatoxin?
questions.solution:
C3b is not an anaphylatoxin. It acts as an opsonin and promotes phagocytosis.

C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a and C3a are called anaphylatoxins because they stimulate histamine release from mast cells and thereby increase vascular permeability and cause vasodilation.

 

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hyperemesis gravidarum is false?

choices.text: More common in the first pregnancy
More common in women with high BMI

questions.solution:
Hyperemesis gravidarum is more common in women with low BMI. The term refers to unrelenting nausea and vomiting that is severe enough to cause weight loss, dehydration, ketosis, alkalosis or hypokalaemia.

It is associated with the following factors:

  • First pregnancy
  • Young age
  • Low body mass
  • History of migraine/motion sickness
  • Positive family history
  • Hydatidiform mole and multi-foetal gestation

questions.text: A patient was evaluated for hearing loss. Rinne’s test shows that air conduction is better than bone conduction in both ears. Weber's test lateralizes to the left ear. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, the inference of the tuning fork tests is Weber's test lateralized to the left ear and Rinne's test normal. So the diagnosis is sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear.

Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time. Some examples of commonly done tuning fork tests are as follows:

Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus (EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC). The inferences are as follows:

  • Rinne's test is considered positive (normal) when the air conduction AC>BC is seen in normal people and people with sensorineural deafness.
  • It is considered negative when the BC>AC, and is seen in patients with conductive deafness. It suggests a minimum hearing loss of 15-20 dB.

 Weber test is done by placing a vibrating tuning in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. The inferences are as follows:

  • Normal result is achieved when the sound heard equally in both ears
  • In conductive deafness, it is lateralized to the worse ear
  • In sensorineural deafness, it is lateralized to the better ear

Other options: 

Option A: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear presents with a negative Rinne's test (BC>AC) and Weber's test lateralized to the right ear. 

Option B: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear presents with a negative Rinne's test (BC>AC)and Weber's test is lateralized towards the left ear.

Option D: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear presents with a positive Rinne's test (AC>BC) and Weber's test is lateralized towards the right ear.

Related Pearl: Tuning fork tests

Tests Normal
Conductive 
loss
Sensorineural
loss
Rinne AC > BC (Rinne +) BC > AC (Rinne -) AC > BC (Rinne +)
Weber Center Lateralized to the affected ear Lateralized to the normal ear
Absolute bone conduction Normal Normal Reduced
Schwabach Normal Lengthened Shortened
Bing Positive Negative Positive
Gelle Positive Negative (ossicular lesions) Positive

AC- Air conduction; BC- Bone conduction.

questions.text: The principal unit of administration in India is ______
questions.solution:
The principal unit of administration in India is the district under a Collector.

Under districts are the subdivisions, tahsils or talukas, municipalities or corporations, villages, panchayats, etc.

As of the 2019 census, there are 725 districts in India.

questions.text: Which of the following Korotkoff sounds corresponds to diastolic blood pressure in a patient with aortic regurgitation?
questions.solution:
Muffled sound corresponds to diastolic blood pressure in aortic regurgitation.

In aortic regurgitation, the pulse pressure is widened and the Korotkoff sounds often do not disappear even when the sphygmomanometer cuff is fully deflated. Hence, diastolic pressure is recorded at the pressure that corresponds to muffling of korotkoff sounds.

questions.text: The following is the finding noted in a 12-month-old baby who is growing well and developing normally since birth. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this finding?

choices.text: Maternal history of phenytoin intake during pregnancy should be suspected
Chromosomal analysis should be done to rule out other chromosomal abnormalities

questions.solution:
The picture depicts a Simian crease – single transverse palmar crease. It is a normal finding in about 3% of the population. And in a child with simian crease and normal growth and development, simple reassurance should be provided.

Other options:

  • A simian crease is one of the findings of Down syndrome however presence of only this finding should not lead to a diagnosis of Down syndrome.
  • Maternal history of phenytoin intake during pregnancy does not lead to this finding. However, maternal alcohol intake can be associated with this condition.
  • Chromosomal analysis in an otherwise well child is not indicated.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple abscesses over his chest and back. The child has a history of atopic skin rashes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the above clinical history and examination, the most probable diagnosis is Hyper-immunoglobulinemia E syndrome (Job’s Syndrome).

It is a rare primary immunodeficiency disease caused due to a failure of neutrophils to generate an immune response, causing elevated IgE levels.

  • It is characterized by recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, recurrent lung infections (pneumatocele), eczema, eosinophilia and high serum levels of lgE
  • The underlying mechanism is due to a defect in neutrophil chemotaxis
  • Autosomal dominant cases are linked to mutations in STAT3 gene
  • Autosomal recessive cases are due to mutations in DOCK8 gene

questions.text: Pertussis toxin acts by which of the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
Pertussis toxin acts by ADP-Ribosylation. It is expressed on the surface of Bordatella pertussis and is secreted into the environment.

Bordatella pertussis is a gram negative capsulated coccobacilli which causes whooping cough/pertussis (pertussis meaning intense cough)

Detection of bacilli in the upper respiratory tract by microscopy or culture confirms diagnosis. Respiratory samples can be collected by per-nasal swab, post-nasal swab or using the cough plate method. 

The Bordet-Gengou medium is used to culture the bacilli which are seen as small, dome-shaped, greyish white, refractile and glistening colonies, resembling 'bisected pearls' or 'mercury drops'. Confluent growth presents an 'aluminium paint' appearance.

 

 

Bordetella pertussis produces 3 hemagglutinins:

  • Pertussis toxin (PT)
  • FHA (Filamentous hemagglutinin)
  • Lipid factor

PT plays a major role in the pathogenesis of whooping cough. It acts by promoting lymphocytosis, increasing sensitization to histamine, and enhanced insulin secretion by means of ADP ribosylation that disrupts function of signal transduction in many cell types. FHA is responsible for facilitating the adhesion of Bordetella pertussis to the respiratory epithelium. FHA and PT also promote secondary infection by coating other bacteria such as Haemophilus influenzae and Pneumococci and assisting their binding to respiratory epithelium. This phenomenon has been termed 'piracy of adhesins'

Whooping cough is treated with erythromycin or one of the newer macrolides such azithromycin.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: Which of the following blot transfer techniques is used to detect specific sequences of DNA?
questions.solution:
Southern blot transfer technique can be used to detect specific sequences of DNA. It involves the following steps.

  • DNA from a cell line or tissue is digested into fragments by restriction enzymes
  • The fragments are embedded in agarose or polyacrylamide gel and subjected to electrophoresis. This separates the fragments based on their charge and size
  • The electrophoresed fragments are then denatured with a mild alkali and transferred to nitrocellulose or nylon paper
  • A labelled DNA probe is added, which hybridizes with complementary strands of DNA
  • The hybridisation is visualised by X-raying the film or using an image screen

Other options:

  • Western blot is used to detect and quantify specific protein molecules
  • Northern blot is used to detect and quantify specific RNA molecules
  • South-western blot or overlay blot is used to examine protein-protein or protein-nucleic acid interactions
