questions.text: A 45-year-old male, known case of HIV presented with facial oedema, and urine analysis revealed albuminuria (4.0 g/d). Blood investigations revealed azotaemia and hypoalbuminemia. A renal biopsy is shown below, what is the most probable finding we can expect?
questions.solution:
The image shown is suggestive of Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). The most probable diagnosis we can expect from the given case scenario is HIV associated nephropathy (HIVAN).

The lesion in HIVAN is FSGS, with a characteristic collapsing glomerulopathy with visceral epithelial cell swelling, microcytic dilatation of renal tubules and tubuloreticular inclusion.

Other options:

  • Minimal change disease is also called as NIL's lesion because there is no abnormality seen in light microscopy of kidney biopsy, but it shows effacement of foot process on electron microscopy.
  • Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN) describes a distinct histologic form of glomerulonephritis, more than 50% of the glomeruli (diffuse) show an increase in mesangial, epithelial, endothelial (proliferative), and inflammatory cells (ie, glomerulonephritis).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition shown below?

choices.text: Histopathology shows excess collagen arranged parallel to each other

questions.solution:
The given image shows a keloid scar. The histology of keloid scars shows excess, thick, wavy collagen fibers in random orientation (predominantly type 3 collagen).

Keloid scars are associated with elevated levels of growth factors.

A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Its etiology is unknown, but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, deeply pigmented skin, and inherited tendencies and certain areas of the body (triangle whose points are the xiphisternum and each shoulder tip).

Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and excision of the keloid scar has a high rate of recurrence.

Treatment:

  • Pressure- local moulds or elastic garments
  • Silicone gel sheeting
  • Intralesional triamcinolone injection
  • Excision and steroid injections
  • Excision and postoperative radiation (external beam or brachytherapy)
  • Intralesional excision
  • Laser to reduce redness
  • Vitamin E and palm oil massage
Features Hypertrophic scar Keloid
Genetic predisposition Not familial May be familial - Autosomal dominant with incomplete penetration
Age Children Adolescents. Middle age
Sex Equal in both More common in females
Race No predilection African American, Asian, Hispanic
Site Anywhere (more common on flexor surfaces) Neck, chest, ear lobes, shoulders, upper back
Timings 4–6 weeks postinjury Symptom-free interval; may appear years after injury
Symptoms Raised, some pruritus respects wound confines Pain, pruritus, hyperesthesia, growth beyond wound margins
Regression Frequent spontaneous No
Contracture Frequent Rare
Histology Parallel orientation of collagen fibers Hypocellular, thick, wavy collagen fibers in random orientation

questions.text: Which of the following factors contributes to pain in spasmodic dysmenorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Progesterone stimulates the secretion of PGF2α, which in turn causes the painful myometrial contractions seen in spasmodic dysmenorrhoea. Vasopressin and endothelin also contribute to the pain by stimulating PGF2α secretion.

Clinical relevance: Since progesterone is mainly secreted by the corpus luteum formed after ovulation, spasmodic dysmenorrhoea is absent in anovulatory cycles.

Other options:

Pelvic venous congestion contributes to pain in congestive dysmenorrhoea.

questions.text: A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with:

choices.text: Mean of 1 and a standard deviation of 0
Mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1

questions.solution:
A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a melatonin receptor agonist?
questions.solution:
Memantine is a glutaminergic NMDA receptor antagonist. It is used in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

Other options:

  • Agomelatine is a melatonin (MT1 and MT2) receptor agonist and 5-HT2C receptor antagonist. It is approved for treatment of major depressive disorder in EU. It increases noradrenaline and dopamine release specifically in the frontal cortex and has no influence on the extracellular levels of serotonin. It also resynchronises circadian rhythms in animal models of circadian rhythm disruption.
  • Ramelteon and Tasimelteon are melatonin receptor agonists indicated in insomnia and non-24-hour sleep-wake disorder respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases the bioavailability of levodopa?
questions.solution:
Pyridoxine abolishes the therapeutic effect of levodopa (not combined with carbidopa) by enhancing its peripheral decarboxylation leading to a decrease in its bioavailability.

Drug interactions of Levodopa:

  • Pyridoxine: Abolishes the therapeutic effect of levodopa.
  • Phenothiazines, butyrophenones, metoclopramide reverse the therapeutic effect of levodopa by blocking DA receptors.
  • Nonselective MAO inhibitors along with levodopa may cause hypertensive crisis.
  • Antihypertensive drugs accentuate the postural hypotension caused by levodopa.
  • Antiparkinsonian anticholinergic drugs have additive therapeutic action with low doses of levodopa, but retard its absorption—more time is available for peripheral degradation—efficacy of levodopa may be reduced.

questions.solution:
Tumbling motility is shown by Listeria monocytogenes.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of hair loss over the back of his head. There is no other significant past medical history. On examination, the following can be seen with exclamation mark hairs without scaling or inflammation. Which of the following is true about the condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of localized hair loss with exclamation mark hairs without scaling or inflammation on examination is suggestive of alopecia areata. Sparing of white hair is seen in alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to non-scarring hair loss. It is thought to be caused by T-cell-mediated autoimmunity(Option A). The activated T lymphocytes invade the hair bulb but the follicle is spared(Option C). It is associated with many autoimmune diseases systemic lupus erythematosus, thyroiditis, vitiligo, and psoriasis. 

It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes (Option D). In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis). The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. Some broken hairs can be seen, which are called exclamation marks. They are easily extractable. It preferentially affects pigmented hair and spares non-pigmented or white hair.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of patients with hair loss that is patchy and is of shorter duration. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. Severe and long-standing alopecia areata require oral corticosteroids.

The image below shows a clinical picture of alopecia areata with a patch of alopecia with a smooth surface of the scalp-

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia 

Mnemonic for causes of non-scarring alopecia: THATS STD!

  • Tinea capitis(Non-Inflammatory Type  - grey patch and black dot types )
  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron 

Mnemonic for causes of scarring alopecia: SF2L3

  • Scleroderma - Linear scalp morphea (en coup de sabre)
  • Favus and Kerion (Inflammatory Type of Tinea capitis)
  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text: Which of the following tests is part of the modified biophysical profile?
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid index is a part of the modified biophysical profile.

The modified biophysical profile includes the following two tests:

  • Vibroacoustic stimulation test (VAST)/Non-stress test (NST)
  • Amniotic fluid index

Biophysical profile or the Manning score includes five tests:

  • B-Breathing movements of fetus
  • A-Amniotic fluid voulme
  • T-Tone of fetus
  • M-Movements of fetus
  • N-Non-stress Test (NST)

(Mnemonic – BATMaN)

questions.text: What is the dose of levonorgestrel in MALA-D?
questions.solution:
The dose of levonorgestrel in MALA-D and MALA-N is 150 mcg. The dose of ethinyl oestradiol in these combined contraceptive pills is 30 mcg. MALA-N is supplied free of cost by the government.

The tablets are present in blister packs having 28 tablets – 21 combined contraceptive pills and 7 ferrous fumarate tablets. One combined contraceptive pill is taken from day 1 to day 21 of the menstrual cycle, preferably at bedtime after a meal. This is followed by a break of seven days to allow for withdrawal bleeding and ferrous fumarate tablets are taken during this period. A new course is commenced afterwards.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Which of the following is the triad of Miller-Fisher syndrome?
questions.solution:
Miller Fisher syndrome is an acquired nerve disease that is considered to be a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome. Like Guillain-Barré syndrome, symptoms may be preceded by a viral illness.

Classically presents as a triad of:

  • Ataxia
  • Areflexia
  • Ophthalmoplegia

Miller-Fisher syndrome:

  • The condition is usually not associated with weakness, if present, is very mild.
  • It is strongly associated with antibodies to the ganglioside.
  • The prognosis for most individuals with Miller Fisher syndrome is good. In most cases, recovery begins within 2 to 4 weeks of the onset of symptoms, and may be almost complete within 6 months. Some individuals are left with residual deficits. Relapses may occur rarely.
  • Treatment for Miller Fisher syndrome is identical to treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome: intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis and supportive care.

questions.text: A patient on examination was found to have contralateral hemisensory loss. Later he developed burning pain in the limbs which responds poorly to analgesic. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture the most probable diagnosis is Thalamic pain syndrome also known as Dejerine Roussy syndrome.

Occlusion of these thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches results in Thalamic pain syndrome.

It is characterized by C/L hemisensory loss which starts as numbness and progresses to cause severe burning pain in the affected regions.

As thalamus is the site for relay of sensory information between the periphery and cortex, a lesion in the thalamus causes a miscommunication between the afferent pathway and cortex of the brain.

This pain responds poorly to analgesics. Anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine or gabapentin or tricyclic antidepressants may be beneficial.

questions.text: Posterior interosseous nerve can be injured in:
questions.solution:
Posterior interosseous nerve can be injured in Monteggia fracture.

There is dislocation of radial head in Monteggia fracture. Posterior interosseous nerve is most commonly injured because of its proximity to the radial head.

Monteggia fracture dislocation can be of the following types:

Type 1: Anterior radial head dislocation.

Type 2: Posterior radial head dislocation.

Type 3: Lateral radial head dislocation.

Type 4: Associated fracture of radius.

 Type 1 is the most common type.

questions.text: The function of malachite green used in Lowenstein-Jensen media is to:
questions.solution:
Malachite green is the selective dye present in the LJ medium to prevent the growth of contaminants.

The selective media for Mycobacterium tuberculosis is Lowenstein–Jensen medium (LJ) medium.

Contents of LJ medium:

  • Malachite green (Prevents growth of contaminants)
  • Egg (provide fatty acids and protein required for the metabolism of mycobacteria).
  • Mineral salt solution (acts as a buffer)
  • Glycerol (Source of carbon, Favours growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis).
  • L-asparagine (Source of Nitrogen)

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of stable tissue?
questions.solution:
Liver parenchyma is an example of stable tissue.

Different tissues have different intrinsic proliferative capacity, which determines their ability to repair themselves. Based on this capacity, the tissues in the body are divided as follows: 

Labile tissues - cells are constantly being lost and must be continuously replaced by new cells that are derived from tissue stem cells. These tissues can readily regenerate after injury as long as the pool of stem cells is preserved.

  • Hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow (Option A)
  • Basal layers of many surface epithelia, such as squamous epithelia of the skin, oral cavity
  • Cuboidal epithelia of the ducts draining exocrine organs e.g., salivary glands, biliary tract
  • Columnar epithelium of the gastrointestinal tract (Option B), uterus, and fallopian tubes
  • Transitional epithelium of the urinary tract

Stable tissues - made up of cells that are normally in the G0 stage of the cell cycle and hence not proliferating, but they are capable of dividing in response to injury.

  • Parenchyma of most solid organs, such as liver, kidney, and pancreas
  • Endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells

Permanent tissues - terminally differentiated non-proliferative cells. Injury to these tissues is irreversible and results in a scar, because the cells cannot regenerate.

  • Majority of neurons
  • Cardiac muscle cells (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is not consistent with an atherosclerotic occlusive disease at the bifurcation of aorta?

choices.text: Claudication of the buttock and thigh

questions.solution:
Gangrene localized to the feet is not a feature of the aortoiliac occlusive disease (AIOD). As it is a chronic arterial disease and thus, the distal circulation (pulses) (eg.dorsalis pedis) is preserved due to the formation of collaterals.

Correlation of clinical findings to the site of disease  Features
Aortoiliac obstruction

Claudication in buttocks, thighs, and calves

Bruit over aortoiliac region

Impotence (Leriche's syndrome)
Iliac obstruction

Claudication of thigh and calf, unilaterally

Absence of femoral and distal pulses

Bruit over iliac region
Femoropopliteal obstruction

Claudication in calf

Femoral pulse felt but distal pulses absent
Distal obstruction

Ankle pulses absent

Claudication in calf and foot

Femoral and popliteal pulses palpable

Obstruction of the superficial femoral artery will cause claudication of buttock or thigh.

CT angiography (CTA) and MR angiography (MRA) are specific investigations. Doppler ultrasound, duplex scanning, and digital subtraction percutaneous angiography (DSA) are the other available investigations.

An aortofemoral bypass is the choice of surgical intervention in aortoiliac obstruction. Dacron graft is a collagen-impregnated, knitted graft that is used to perform the proximal aortic anastomosis in aortofemoral bypass. It can also be used in aortic valve repair. In unfit patients, axillofemoral bypass may be done.

Leriche syndrome is due to occlusion at the aortic bifurcation and is characterized by:

  • Buttock claudication
  • Impotence  
  • Absence of femoral pulse.
  • No sensory or motor deficit
  • Normal refluxes

Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of Leriche syndrome. 

Differential diagnosis includes:

  • Abdominal dissection 
  • Spinal canal stenosis 
  • Spinal disc herniation
Intermittent claudication Neurogenic claudication Osteoarthritis
Pain after walking a certain distance Pain after walking or standing for some time Maximum pain on the first step.
Pain quickly relieved on resting. Pain relieved on flexion Pain relieved on resting.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with a painless swelling in front of the ear as given below. On examination, his left earlobe was lifted and the curtain sign was positive. What is the mainstay treatment of this condition where only the superficial lobe is involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of parotid pleomorphic adenoma and the mainstay treatment in this condition is superficial parotidectomy. 

Pleomorphic adenomas are benign mixed neoplasms presenting as a painless and slow-growing swelling that lifts the ear lobe. This swelling cannot be moved above the zygomatic bone and is known as the curtain sign. 

Sometimes it may undergo malignant transformation. The malignant form is known as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma. Signs of malignant transformation include:

  • A rapid increase in size
  • Pain and ulceration
  • Facial nerve involvement (LMN)
  • Lymph node involvement
  • Restricted jaw movements

Surgical intervention is done via parotidectomy. If only the superficial lobe is involved superficial parotidectomy (removal of the superficial lobe) is done. 

If both lobes are involved, total conservative parotidectomy (both lobes are removed but the facial nerve is preserved) or total radical parotidectomy (both lobes and facial nerve are removed - malignant cases) can be done. 

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents with a red and pruritic rash on the sun-exposed areas of the body, along with a history of frequent falls, diarrhea, and dysentery. She was diagnosed with Hartnup disease. What causes these pellagra-like features in Hartnup disease?

choices.text: Excessive loss of niacin in urine

questions.solution:
Malabsorption of tryptophan leads to pellagra in Hartnup disease.

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive condition caused by a defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan due to the mutation of the SLC6A19 gene on chromosome 5. As a result, the production of niacin from tryptophan is reduced, and this manifests as pellagra, with dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and glossitis. A characteristic skin rash called Casal’s necklace may also be seen.

Clinical features include intermittent, reversible episodes affecting the skin and nervous system that are aggravated by sunlight, febrile illness, stress, and nutritional deficiency. Skin manifestations present after sun exposure and include erythematous, scaly patches, similar to pellagra. Neurologic manifestations include ataxia, tremor, mood disorder, depression, convulsions, and psychosis.

Diagnosis is made by demonstrating the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine, thus distinguishing it from pellagra. Urine may also contain indican, which is produced as a by-product of tryptophan metabolism. 

Casal’s necklace:

Niacin (Vitamin B3)

It is synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan. The active forms of niacin are nicotinic acid and nicotinamide. Nicotinamide is present in NAD and NADP, which are important for oxidation-reduction reactions and ADP ribosylation of proteins involved in the DNA repair mechanism.  

Deficiency of niacin causes pellagra. Important causes are as follows:

  • Dietary deficiencies of niacin or tryptophan
  • Hartnup disease- defective absorption of tryptophan
  • Carcinoid syndrome- enterochromaffin cells increase the production of 5-hydroxytryptamine. This decreases the production of niacin.

Excessive levels of niacin cause dilation of blood vessels, flushing, skin irritation, and liver damage.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes catalyses the rate limiting step in bile acid synthesis?
questions.solution:
Conversion of cholesterol to 7-alpha hydroxycholesterol is the rate limiting step in bile acid synthesis and is catalysed by 7-alpha hydroxylase.

Vitamin C is a co-factor of this enzyme and hence, enzyme activity is reduced in vitamin C deficiency. Feedback inhibition by bile acid acting through farnesoid X receptor also reduces enzyme activity.

Other options:

HMG CoA reductase is the rate limiting step in cholesterol synthesis.

questions.text: The wrong statement with reference to synovial cell sarcoma:
questions.solution:
Synovial sarcomas a greater tendency to occur in young adults.

The diagnosis of synovial sarcoma is typically made based on histology and is confirmed by the presence of t(x;18).This translocation takes place between the SYT gene on chromosome 18 and one of three SSX genes on chromosome X forming a SYT-SSX fusion gene.

Two cell types can be seen in histology of synovial sarcoma.One is fibrous and other epithelial in appearance.

Most tumors are located in distal extremities including the hand and are the most common soft tissue sarcoma of foot.

questions.text: How do prostaglandin analogues reduce intra-ocular pressure?
questions.solution:
Prostaglandin analogues reduce IOP primarily by increasing the uveoscleral outflow. They also improve trabecular outflow to a minor degree.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: The cut-off value for treatment in neonatal hypogylcemia is ________
questions.solution:
The cut-off for the treatment of neonatal hypoglycemia is a Blood glucose level of <40 mg/dL ( Plasma glucose <45 mg/dL).

This is particularly applicable after the initial 2–3 hours of life. Babies showing Plasma glucose <45 mg/dL (Blood glucose <40 mg/dL) on a reagent strip should be treated for hypoglycemia. Since reagent strips have high false-positive rates, a confirmation of hypoglycemia by a lab test is recommended.

Neonatal hypoglycemia:

  • Plasma glucose <45 mg/dL
  • Blood glucose <40 mg/dL

questions.text: A patient comes to a private practitioner and was diagnosed with tuberculosis. Within how many days does he have to report or inform the District Health Officer?
questions.solution: The guidelines for TB notification under the RNTCP is within 30 days (a month) of receiving a new case. The notification must be done to the District Health Officer or the Chief Medical Officer of a District Hospital by the practitioner who diagnosed it.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea is found to have a blind-ended vagina. Breast development is adequate and stature is normal while pubic and axillary hairs are sparse. USG reveals absent uterus and the karyotype is 46, XY. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history and the examination findings suggest a diagnosis of androgen insensitivity syndrome.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome, formerly called testicular feminization syndrome, is a condition in which the end organs are unable to respond to the androgen. There is either a mutation or lack of the androgen cytosol receptor 

They are phenotypically and psychosocially a female. 

They present with primary amenorrhea or infertility. The breast is well developed with absent or sparse axillary and pubic hair. The vagina is short and blind. The uterus is absent. It is due to the normal production of antimullerian hormone by the Sertoli cells. Testes may be in either the labia or inguinal canal or intrabdominal area. Karyotype is 46, XY.

Other options:

Options A and C: Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome, has a karyotype of 46XX. Similar to androgen insensitivity syndrome, these females present with primary amenorrhea with normal breast development and an absent uterus. However, ovaries are present. 

Option D: In Turner syndrome, short stature with poor development of secondary sexual characters will be seen. It has a karyotype of 45 XO. Sex chromatin is negative. Female genital organs (vagina, uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries) are present.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used to treat HCV have the least chance of developing resistance?
questions.solution:
Sofosbuvir, a nucleotide NS5B polymerase inhibitor has the least chance of developing resistance.

Nucleotide NS5B polymerase inhibitors have a high genetic barrier to resistance for HCV; three or more resistant associated variants (RAVs) are required for full resistance.

Nonnucleoside NS5B polymerase inhibitors, NS5A inhibitors (ombitasvir, and velpatasvir) and NS3 protease inhibitors (like grazoprevir) have low genetic barrier for the development of resistance. Only one or two amino acid substitutions result in lack of drug efficacy.

questions.text: Remodeling of scar tissue does not involve:
questions.solution:
Fibroblast proliferation occurs during scar formation. It does not contribute to scar remodeling.

Remodeling of the scar increases its strength and contracts it. The following changes contribute to scar remodeling:

  • Cross linking of collagen- causing contraction
  • Increased size of collagen fibres
  • Shift from type III collagen to more resilient type I collagen

questions.text: Which of the following is not a neurodegenerative disease?
questions.solution:
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is a demyelinating disease.

Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the progressive loss of neurons, typically affecting groups of neurons with functional interconnections:

  • Hippocampus and associated cortices - present with cognitive changes, often including disturbances of memory, behavior, and language as in Alzheimer's disease.
  • Basal ganglia- manifest as movement disorders; these may be hypokinetic, as with Parkinson's disease, or hyperkinetic, as with Huntington disease.
  • Cerebellum or its input and output circuitry- result in ataxia, as in the spinocerebellar ataxias.
  • Motor system-weakness and difficulty with swallowing and respiration, as with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER with breathlessness and hypotension. On examination, there were soft heart sounds and JVP was elevated. A transthoracic echocardiography revealed an accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space. Which of the following can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space suggests pericardial tamponade. Electrical alternans is seen in pericardial tamponade.

In tamponade, the ventricular filling is limited because ventricles cannot expand into the fluid-filled pericardial cavity. This leads to a reduction in cardiac output and arterial pressure as well. The three cardinal features of tamponade are given by Beck's triad, and include hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds, and distension of the jugular veins.

There is a prominent x descent in JVP but absent y descent. Paradoxical pulse, which refers to a drop of SBP >10 mmHg during inspiration, is also seen in tamponade. Although more likely to indicate tamponade, paradoxical pulse can also be seen in constrictive pericarditis and chronic obstructive airway disease. ECG in tamponade shows electrical alternans, which refers to alternating QRS amplitudes as shown in the ECG given below.

 

On the other hand, the main abnormality which occurs in constrictive pericarditis is the inability of the ventricles to fill because of the rigid and thickened pericardium. Unlike tamponade, this restriction is not uniform through the diastole. Ventricular filling is normal early in the diastole but stops suddenly when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. Y-descent on the JVP curve is prominent (option A) in constrictive pericarditis because it represents the rapid early filling of the ventricles. A sudden stop in ventricular filling due to pericardial knock (option D) and subsequent rising pressure is seen as a square root sign in the JVP curve.

There may be a paradoxical rise in venous pressure during inspiration, known as Kussmaul's sign (option C). The ECG often shows low-voltage QRS complexes and diffuse flattening of T-waves.

questions.text: The normal mean corpuscular volume is:
questions.solution:
The normal mean corpuscular volume is 81- 97 fL.

RBC Indices:

Mean cell volume (MCV)-  81–97 fL

Mean cell Hb (MCH)- 28–34 pg

Mean cell Hb concentration (MCHC)-  33–35 g/dL

questions.text: Which of the following is used in laser enucleation of the prostate?
questions.solution:
Ho-YAG laser is the most common laser used in enucleation of the prostate. The procedure is known as Holmium laser enucleation of the prostate (HoLEP).

Laser reduce the duration of the procedure and the risk of harmorrhage.

KTPA green light laser is the best laser that can be used. It causes vaporisation of prostatic tissue. As it is hemostatic in nature, it can be safely used in patients on anticoagulants.

Related Pearl: Lasers used in various specialities

questions.text: Total communication (TC) is used for _______.
questions.solution:
The philosophy of total communication is used in the education of deaf children. It requires incorporation of aural, oral, and manual modes of communication for effective communication with and among hearing-impaired people.

World Deaf Day 2019 will be celebrated at last Monday (30th of September) in the month of September to draw the attention of the general public, politicians and development authorities towards the achievements of the deaf people.

questions.text: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a late complication caused by infection with?
questions.solution:
SSPE (subacute sclerosing panencephalitis), also known as Dawson disease is caused by infection with measles virus.

  • It is a slowly progressive disease characterized by seizures and progressive deterioration of cognitive and motor functions, with death occurring 5–15 years after measles virus infection.
  • MIBE: Measles inclusion body encephalitis is a rare but fatal complication that affects individuals with defective cellular immunity and typically occurs months after measles infection.

questions.text: Which of the following show an increased DLCO?
questions.solution:
Increased DLCO is seen in bronchial asthma. 

Diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) reflects the ability of lungs to transfer gas across the alveolar-capillary interface. The following disorders are associated with increased DLCO:

  • Obesity
  • Asthma
  • High altitude
  • Polycythemia
  • Pulmonary alveolar hemorrhage
  • Left-to-right intracardiac shunting
  • Mild left heart failure (due to increased pulmonary capillary blood volume)
  • Exercise just prior to the test session (due to increased cardiac output)
  • Supine position; Mueller maneuver (inhalation against closed glottis decreases intrathoracic pressure and increases blood return to the lungs)

Note: Emphysema, ILD, and pulmonary vascular disease are associated with lowered DLCO. Alveolar haemorrhage is associated with an increase in DLCO.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency department having sustained severe blunt trauma to the abdomen. His vitals are Pulse:112/min, BP 80/50mmHg, GCS is 14 and the peripheries are cold.  The best diagnostic that you can perform for this patient is:
questions.solution:
The best diagnostic modality for hemodynamically unstable patients with blunt trauma of the abdomen is Ultrasound Abdomen (FAST scan -Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma).

The tachycardia, cold peripheries and the BP being 80/50 mm Hg, indicate the patient is hemodynamically unstable. Hence he is not to be shifted for the sake of a CT scan and instead, a bedside FAST/E-FAST scan should be performed. 

Note: The best diagnostic modality for hemodynamically stable patients with blunt trauma of the abdomen is CT Scan.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the role of acetyl CoA in gluconeogenesis?

choices.text: Acts as a substrate of pyruvate carboxylase

questions.solution:
Acetyl CoA promotes gluconeogenesis by allosteric activation of pyruvate carboxylase and increases the production of oxaloacetate from pyruvate.

It also inhibits glycolysis by allosteric inhibition of pyruvate dehydrogenase. These actions are responsible for the transition from glycolysis in the fed state to gluconeogenesis in the fasting state.

questions.text: The contribution of employer in ESI scheme is:
questions.solution:
The contribution of employer in ESI scheme is 3.25%

The state government share of expenditure on medical care is 1/8, the ESI corporation's share of expenditure on medical care is 7/8th of the total cost.

Few important points to be known about the ESI act:

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employer contributes 3.25% of the total wage bill.
  • Employee contributes 0.75% of wages.
  • State and Central government share medical expenditure in the ratio 1:7.
  • Medical benefit: Full medical care
  • Sickness benefit: 70% of the average daily wages and is payable for 91 days.
  • Extended sickness benefit: Payable for 2 years for a set of 34 diseases.
  • Enhanced sickness benefit: Full average daily wage for a duration up to 7 days in case of vasectomy and up to 14 days in case of tubectomy.
  • Maternity benefit: Full average daily wage for a duration up to 26 weeks (confinement) or 6 weeks (miscarriage/MTP) or 4 weeks (sickness arising out of pregnancy).
  • Funeral expenses: Cash not exceeding Rs.15,000.

questions.text: Which of the following can be associated with focal ataxia?
questions.solution:
Cerebellar haemorrhage can cause focal ataxia.

Focal ataxia is often caused by cerebrovascular disease, most commonly due to ischemic stroke or cerebellar hemorrhage. These lesions generally result in cerebellar symptoms on the same side as the affected area.

All the mentioned causes result in symmetrical ataxia

Drugs:

  • Phenytoin
  • Lithium
  • Barbiturates
  • Fluorouracil
  • Paclitaxel

Postinfectious syndrome:

  • Varicella
  • Poliovirus
  • Coxsackievirus
  • Echovirus
  • Epstein-Barr virus
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Legionella
  • Lyme disease

Malnutrition/Deficency:

  • Vitamin B1 (thiamine)
  • Vitamin B12 (cobalamine)

Intoxification/exposure:

  • Alcohol 
  • Toluene exposure
  • Gasoline sniffing
  • Glue sniffing, spray painting
  • Methyl mercury
  • Bismuth

Others:

  • Paraneoplastic syndromes
  • Hyponatremia

questions.text: Antibodies in Devic’s disease targets?
questions.solution:
Antibodies in Devic’s disease (Neuromyelitis Optica) target Aquaporin 4.

Anti-Jo-1 antibody, most commonly found in patients with idiopathic inflammatory myopathies targets histidyl-tRNA synthetase.

The ataxic syndrome associated with Anti‐Yo antibody, or Purkinje cell cytoplasmic antibody type 1 (PCA1), is the most common variant of paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration and it targets Human cerebellar degeneration-related protein-2.

Anti-Ro/SSA and Anti-La/SSB targets Ro/SSA and La/SSB in Sjogren’s Syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following findings in the patient's better eye would prompt you to not classify the patient as blind as per the WHO criteria?
questions.solution:
Visual acuity of 3/60 in the better eye is classified as severe visual impairment.

As per WHO's definition, blindness is defined as presenting visual acuity of worse than 3/60 or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10° in the better eye. Presenting visual acuity in the range of worse than 6/18 to 6/60 is defined as moderate visual impairment. Presenting visual acuity of worse than 6/60 to 3/60 (including 3/60) is classified as severe visual impairment.

The other options with visual fields of 4 and 8 degrees and visual acuity of 1/60 in the better eye are all classified as blindness.

questions.text: Schwann cells are derived from:
questions.solution:
Schwann cells are derived from Neural crest cells.

Related Pearl: Neural crest derivatives

Neural

questions.text: In which of the following conditions are pseudobuboes found?
questions.solution:
Pseudobuboes are seen in granuloma inguinale. They are a subcutaneous extension of granulomas that mimic enlarged lymph nodes.

Buboes are enlarged, tender, painful glands in the groin. They are found in LGV and chancroid.

LGV- The lymphadenopathy is usually unilateral. About one‐third of patients may have the characteristic ‘groove sign’ – a groove‐like depression caused by femoral and inguinal lymph node enlargement above and below the inguinal ligament.

Chancroid- in over one‐third of cases, there is accompanying inguinal lymphadenitis which may progress to suppurating bubo formation. These are usually unilateral and may become fluctuant and rupture spontaneously to form inguinal ulcers and sinuses.

Primary syphilis- The appearance of the genital and perianal chancre is followed by swelling of the inguinal lymph nodes.

questions.text: Warm antibody immunohemolytic anaemia commonly involves:
questions.solution:
Warm antibody type is the most common form of immune hemolytic anemia. Most causative antibodies are of the IgG class; less commonly, IgA antibodies are involved.

About 50% of cases are idiopathic (primary).

Red cell hemolysis is mostly extravascular.

IgG-coated red cells bind to Fc receptors on phagocytes, which remove red cell membrane during “partial” phagocytosis.

The loss of membrane converts the red cells to spherocytes, which are sequestered and destroyed in the spleen.

Moderate splenomegaly is usually seen.

In many cases, the antibodies are directed against the Rh blood group antigens.

Related Pearl: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia

Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA): A comparison of types

Warm agglutinin AIHA Cold agglutinin AIHA
Etiology

Drugs (e.g., penicillin)

Viral infections

Autoimmune(e.g., SLE)

Immunodeficiency states

Lymphoproliferative (e.g., CLL)

Infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae and EBV)

Lymphoproliferative diseases

 

 

 

Clinical presentation

Direct Coombs’ positive with anti-IgG, anti-C3, or both

 

 

Livedo reticularis and acral cyanosis with cold exposure that disappears with warming

Direct Coombs’ positive with anti-C3 or anti-IgM, but usually not IgG.

Complications

Venous thromboembolism

Lymphoproliferative disorders

Ischemia and peripheral gangrene

Lymphoproliferative disorders
Treatment

Steroids, splenectomy, rituximab

Avoid cold exposure, rituximab

(No role for steroids, splenectomy, or IVIG)

questions.text: A man presents with pain in the ear. Otoscopy shows pearly white debris. A diagnosis of keratosis obturans is made. This condition occurs due to:
questions.solution:
Keratosis obturans occurs due to desquamated epithelial cells.

It is usually seen between the ages of 5-20 years and is commonly unilateral. Clinical features include severe otalgia and difficulty in hearing. It is associated with systemic conditions like bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis. 

On otoscopic examination, there is a thickening of the tympanic membrane and a keratin plug appearing like a pearly white mass occluding the canal. The keratin that is shed from the entire circumference of the deep ear canal appears to have an onion skin arrangement. There is also hyperemia of canal skin, sometimes with ulcerations and granulations. 

Sometimes, the extent of bone absorption is such that it leaves the facial nerve exposed to injury and subsequent paralysis. Extensive erosion of the bone can also result in automastoidectomy.

Treatment involves the removal of the plug by syringing or instrumentation. Any recurrence can be prevented with the use of keratolytic such as 2% salicylic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following is decreased in haemolytic anaemia?
questions.solution:
Haptoglobin levels decrease in hemolytic anemia.

Haptoglobin is synthesized by the liver. It binds to free hemoglobin and prevents its excretion in urine. The haptoglobin-hemoglobin complex is rapidly destroyed by the mononuclear phagocytes. Hence, haptoglobin levels decrease in the presence of free hemoglobin as seen in hemolytic anemia.

LDH, free Hb, and methemoglobin are elevated in hemolysis.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of the ECG given below?
questions.solution:
The ECG provided has characteristic J waves/Osborn waves diagnostic of Hypothermia.

Other options:

  • Hyperkalemia: Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia.
  • Hypokalemia: U waves are seen in hypokalemia.
  • Hypocalcemia: Prolonged QTc interval, occasional T wave inversion.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause permanent impairment of fingerprint pattern?
questions.solution:
Among the given conditions, electrical injury is most likely to cause permanent impairment of fingerprint patterns.

Some changes in fingerprints include:

  • Moderate epidermal ridge atrophy and loss of pattern in celiac disease
  • Incomplete atrophy of the ridges in dermatitis
  • Ridge alteration occurs in eczema, acanthosis nigricans, scleroderma, and dry or atrophic skin
  • Permanent impairment of the fingerprint pattern occurs in leprosy, electric injury, and after exposure to radiation
  • Distance between the ridges is changed, but the pattern is not altered in infantile paralysis, rickets, and acromegaly

Other options:

First-degree burns (option A) cannot cause permanent damage to the fingerprints. Fingerprints are better protected than other parts of the body in case of burns as they are bent inwards against the palm of the hand.

In decomposed bodies (option C), the skin is found loose like a glove, which is removed, preserved in formalin, and used for impressions. Prints can be obtained from the dermis after the epidermis is lost.

If the fingers are mummified (option D), their outline can be made level by injecting liquid paraffin or formalin.

questions.text: A multipara with previous history of preterm birth presents at 16 weeks of gestation. Transvaginal sonography reveals a cervical length of 23 mm. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The ACOG recommends cervical cerclage for women with previous history of preterm births and cervical length less than 25 mm on transvaginal sonography.

In women with a history of preterm births, transvaginal USG is performed every 2 weeks between 16-24 weeks of age. If the cervical length is between 25-29 mm, USG is repeated after 1 week. If less than 25 mm, cerclage is offered to the expectant mother.

questions.text: The surgical approach to a malignant retrosternal goitre is via:
questions.solution:
The surgical approach to malignant retrosternal goitre is via median sternotomy.

Retrosternal goitre:

It arises from the slow growth of a multinodular gland down into the mediastinum. It is of two types:

1) Primary mediastinal goitre-

  • Seen in 10% cases.
  • Due to ectopic thyroid tissue in the mediastinum
  • Blood supply is from mediastinal vessels.

2) Secondary retrosternal goitre

  • Seen in 90% of cases
  • Thyroid tissue from the neck extends to the retrosternal region.
  • Blood supply is from thyroid vessels.

C/F - Dyspnoea, stridor, dilated neck veins.

Pemberton’s sign - Facial or conjunctival congestion seen on raising of hands above the head.

Investigation - CECT done to assess the extent.

Management - Surgery done most commonly via neck incision.

Indications for median sternotomy -

  • Primary mediastinal goitre
  • Malignant retrosternal goitre
  • Very large retrosternal goitre
  • Recurrence in mediastinum

questions.text: Which of the following causes vasoconstriction of the pulmonary arterioles?
questions.solution:
Unlike the systemic vasculature, the pulmonary vasculature undergoes vasoconstriction in response to hypoxia and resulting low pH/CO2 buildup. This serves to redirect pulmonary blood flow from poorly oxygenated areas to areas rich in oxygen. 

Nitric oxide and sildenafil are vasodilators.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of primary hypercoagulability?
questions.solution:
Primary (inherited) hypercoagulability is most often caused by mutations in the factor V and prothrombin genes.

Leiden mutation - The mutation alters an amino acid residue in factor V and renders it resistant to proteolysis by protein C. Thus, an important anti-thrombotic counter-regulatory mechanism is lost.

Related Pearl: Hypercoagulable states

Primary (Genetic Conditions):

  • Mutations in factor V (Most common)
  • Antithrombin III deficiency
  • Protein C or S deficiency
  • Fibrinolysis defects
  • Homocysteinemia
  • Allelic variations in prothrombin levels
  • Mutations in the methyl tetra hydro folate (MTHF) gene

Secondary (Acquired Conditions):

  • Prolonged bed rest or immobilization
  • Homocysteinemia
  • Tissue damage (Surgery, fracture, burns)
  • Cancer
  • Myocardial infarction, Prosthetic cardiac valves
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odor. The saline microscopy of the vaginal smear showed the following finding. Which of the following is used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing clue cells suggest bacterial vaginosis. Clindamycin is used to treat this condition. 

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection characterized by malodorous (fishy smell) vaginal discharge. Causative organisms include:

  • Gardnerella
  • Haemophilus vaginalis
  • Mobiluncus
  • Mycoplasma hominis 

This is due to the alteration in the normal vaginal flora which causes a decrease in the number of lactobacilli. It mainly reduces the pH and has antibacterial action by releasing hydrogen peroxide.

Amsel's Criteria: (any 3 should be present)

  • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge
  • A pH of vaginal fluid >4.5
  • Fishy odor of discharge accentuated on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test)
  • Presence of Clue cells on microscopy. Many epithelial cells present granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering on their surface, these cells are called clue cells.  

Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells with their surface covered by adherent bacilli seen in stained or unstained films. 

The treatment regimens for bacterial vaginosis are:

  • Tablet metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days
  • Clindamycin cream intravaginally for 7 days
  • Metronidazole gel intravaginally for 5 days

Other drugs that can be used include tinidazole and secnidazole.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for renal scarring in reflux nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is used in renal imaging to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in paediatric imaging for detection of scarring and pyelonephritis.

  • DMSA is an ideal agent for the assessment of renal cortex as it binds to the sulfhydryl groups in proximal tubules at the renal cortex with longer retention than other agents.
  • It allows better assessment of differential renal function. It is a static scan as opposed to dynamic DTPA or MAG3 scans.

Other Options:

  • Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion and hence used for direct measurement of GFR.
  • Tc-99m MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) is excreted through renal route via both glomeruli infiltration and tubular excretion; hence, in paediatric patients and patients with poor renal function this test is considered superior to DTPA scan.
  • The screening investigation used in renovascular hypertension is Captopril DTPA and gold standard investigation is renal angiography.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding measles?

choices.text: The period of infectivity is 3 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash
The most common complication is acute otitis media
Both Koplik spots and Warthin–Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic for measles
Most common cause of death is encephalitis

questions.solution:
Most common complication of measles is acute otitis media, where as most common cause of death is Pneumonia.

Measles (Rubeola):

  • Causative agent: RNA paramyxovirus
  • Source: Droplet infection
  • The secondary attack rate is ≥90%
  • Period of communicability: -3 to +5 days after the appearance of rash
  • The rash appears on 4th day of fever, most common site: face, retroauricular
  • Both Koplik spots and Warthin–Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic for measles
  • Most common cause of death: Pneumonia
  • Diseases associated: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis, multiple sclerosis, Crohn's disease
  • Vaccine: Live attenuated, Edmonston–Zagreb strain or combined MMR given at 9 months of age

Note: The most common complication of chickenpox is secondary bacterial infections.

questions.text: Tzanck cells are seen in infection with?
questions.solution:
Tzanck smear is seen in infection with varicella-zoster virus.

  • The smears prepared from the lesions, from the base of the vesicles and stained with 1% toluidine blue solution.
  • Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogenously stained “ground-glass” chromatin cells constitute the Tzanck cells.
  • These cells are also seen in herpes virus infections.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with a history of epigastric pain, nausea, and occasional episodes of vomiting. An upper GI endoscopy revealed large gastric folds. A biopsy revealed massive foveolar hyperplasia and a marked reduction in oxyntic glands and parietal cells. What is the first line treatment of this disease?
questions.solution:
The above case scenario is suggestive of Menetrier’s disease, first line treatment for which is, Cetuximab, an EGFR inhibitor.

Hypo-proteinemic hypertrophic gastropathy also known as Menetrier's disease is a rare, acquired premalignant disease of the stomach characterized by massive gastric folds, little or no acid production, and excessive mucous production with resultant protein loss. The disorder is associated with excessive secretion of transforming growth factor alpha.

Increased epidermal growth factor (EGF) receptor signalling has been implicated in the pathogenesis of MD. Cetuximab blocks this signalling pathway and showed statistically significant improvement both clinically (quality-of-life indices) and biochemical parameters.

Other options:

  • Total gastrectomy is done if:
    • Severe disease
    • Not responding to first line treatment
  • Nissen’s fundoplication is the treatment of GERD.

questions.text: Identify the components of the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing tool.
questions.solution:
The components of the CRISPR-9 gene-editing tool are guide RNA and Cas9 nuclease.

CRISPR-Cas9 is a genome editing tool and this system enables select bacteria to respond to and eliminate invading genetic material. It uses guide RNA transcribed from CRISPR DNA (Clustered Regularly Interspersed Palindromic Repeats of DNA) and a Cas9 (CRISPR-associated protein 9) nuclease.

The guide RNA targets and binds to specific complementary sequences of DNA which are then cleaved by Cas9. Following cleavage of the targeted DNA sequence, the natural DNA repair process can be allowed to proceed or a new sequence can be inserted.

This technique can be used for gene deletion, gene editing, gene visualization, and modulation of gene transcription.

The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2020 was awarded jointly to Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer A. Doudna for the development of the CRISPR/ Cas9 gene-editing system, which has for the first time enabled scientists to make precise changes in the long stretches of DNA.

questions.text: Cyclo-developmental type of biological transmission is seen in:
questions.solution:
Filariasis is an example of cyclo-developmental type of biological transmission where the microfilaria undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: A 55-year-old construction factory worker presents with dyspnoea. He has been working in this industry for the past 25 years. Which is the most specific malignancy that we can expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Construction factory workers show an increased risk of exposure to asbestos. The most specific malignancy we can expect in this patient is malignant mesothelioma.

Malignant mesothelioma is a rare malignant tumour of the pleura, associated with heavy asbestos exposure. The lifetime risk of developing mesothelioma in heavily exposed individuals is as high as 7% to 10%.

Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung. Characteristic findings include:

  • Irregular or linear opacities - Pleural plaques that are usually first noted in the lower lung fields are the chest radiographic hallmark of asbestosis.
  • An indistinct heart border or a “ground-glass” appearance in the lung fields may be seen.
  • Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity along with mild airflow obstruction (due to peribronchiolar fibrosis).
  • Lung cancer is the most common asbestos-related cancer.
  • Mesothelioma (pleural and peritoneal) is the most specific asbestos-related cancer.

questions.text: A 16-month-child is brought with a history of abdominal distension and delayed mental development. On examination, the cornea is cloudy and there appears to be hepatosplenomegaly. The radiograph of the child is given below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is Hurler's syndrome.

As the child presents with mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea and given x-ray shows a J-shaped sella turcica and a thickened calvaria, the most likely diagnosis is Hurler's Syndrome.

Hurler's syndrome is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 1. This is due to the defect in the α-L iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparan sulphate and dermatan sulphate.

Radiological features in Hurler Syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • J-shaped sella (seen in above radiograph)
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs (seen below)
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

 

Other options:

Option A- Tay-Sachs disease is a hereditary neurodegenerative disorder due to the deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase-A resulting in the excess storage of GM2 ganglioside within the lysosomes of cells. The clinical features include developmental delay, intellectual impairment, seizures, and breathing difficulty.

The CT image shows macrocephaly and reduced attenuation of the cerebral white matter. MRI can delineate deep white matter demyelination, and indicate calcification in thalami on T2 weighted sequences.

Option C- Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder characterized by autosomal recessive inheritance due to the deficiency of the glucocerebrosidase enzyme. This results in the accumulation of a glycolipid (glucocerebroside) within the lysosomes of macrophages.

The clinical features include bone pain, pathological fractures, bone crises hepatosplenomegaly, and hematological disturbances.

The radiological features of the skeletal involvement include osteopenia, osteonecrosis, fractures (pathological), Erlenmeyer flask deformity, and H-shaped vertebra.

Option D- Hunter's disease is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 2 resulting from the deficiency of iduronate sulfatase. This causes the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

The clinical features include abnormal facies characterized by the prominent forehead, flattened nasal bridge, coarse facies, gingival hyperplasia, macroglossia, short stature, dysostosis multiplex, macrocephaly, intellectual disability, hepatosplenomegaly.

These patients lack clouding of the cornea.

The radiological features include thickened calvaria, enlargement of the skull, broad clavicle and ribs, thoracolumbar kyphosis, hip dysplasia, and genu valgum deformity.

questions.text: Which of the following changes in the respiratory epithelium is caused by vitamin A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Vitamin A deficiency induces squamous metaplasia in the respiratory epithelium.

Metaplasia is a reversible replacement of one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal) by another cell type.

Tissue Metaplasia
Airways Squamous metaplasia: Normal pseudostratified epithelium is replaced by the squamous epithelium. The condition may occur due to chronic smoking.   Also, a deficiency of retinoic acid may cause squamous metaplasia.
Urinary bladder Squamous metaplasia: The presence of bladder stones may trigger metaplasia, where the normal transitional epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium.
Esophagus Columnar metaplasia: In patients with chronic GERD, the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barrett's esophagus)
Cervix Squamous metaplasia: Due to the low pH of the cervix, the normal glandular epithelium may be replaced by the squamous epithelium.
Muscle Connective tissue metaplasia: In some cases, after intramuscular hemorrhage, there may be the formation of bone in the muscle tissue; the condition is known as myositis ossificans.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids combines with palmitoyl CoA in the synthesis of ceramide?
questions.solution: Serine and palmitoyl CoA are needed for the synthesis of ceramide which is the common precursor of all sphingolipids.

questions.text: Identify the type of astigmatism in an eye where the vertical and horizontal meridians are the principal meridians and the vertical meridian is more curved:
questions.solution:

questions.text: TNM staging of renal cell carcinoma grossly extending into the inferior vena cava without any metastasis or lymph node spread will be
questions.solution:

T3a: Tumor grossly extends into the renal vein or its segmental (muscle-containing) branches, or tumor invades perirenal and/or renal sinus fat but not beyond Gerota's fascia

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contribute to arteriolar dilation in muscles during exercise?
questions.solution:
Endothelin does not contribute to arteriolar dilation during exercise.

Oxygen deficiency, release of adenosine from hypoxic tissues and increased levels of lactate, potassium and carbon dioxide all cause vasodilation of muscle arterioles.

questions.text: If fluid is irrigated through a cannula in the lacrimal punctum, where should the fluid end up draining if the duct is still patent?
questions.solution:
Nasolacrimal duct runs downwards,backwards, and laterally from the lacrimal sac and opens into the inferior meatus. Hence, fluid that is irrigated through a cannula in the lacrimal punctum will end up in the inferior nasal meatus.

It is bounded by a mucosal valve called the valve of Hasner in the inferior meatus.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of cancer cervix?
questions.solution:
Early diagnosis and treatment is the best level of prevention of cancer cervix.

Early detection and treatment are the main interventions of disease control. The earlier a disease is diagnosed and treated the better it is from the point of view of prognosis and preventing the occurrence of further cases (secondary cases) or any long term disability. This is of particular importance in chronic diseases.

Early diagnosis and treatment though not as effective and economical as primary prevention may be critically important in reducing the high morbidity and mortality in diseases such as essential hypertension, cancer cervix and breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a contra-indication for contraception with centchroman?
questions.solution:
Among the given conditions, centchroman is contra-indicated in polycystic ovary disease.

Endometriosis and breast carcinoma are not-contraindications since centchroman has anti-estrogenic effect on the breast and endometrial tissue. Centchroman doesn't cause osteoporosis as it has a pro-estrogenic effect on the bone. 

Centchroman (Ormeloxifene):

Dose: - For the first 12 weeks - Two 30 mg tablets per week

After 12 weeks - One 30 mg tablet per week

Mechanism of action – It is a non-steroidal selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that prevents implantation by causing endometrial changes. It competitively inhibits estrogen action at the endometrial receptor site.

Fertility returns within 6 months of discontinuing the drug.

Side effects:

  • Prolonged menstrual cycles and oligomenorrhoea
  • Weight gain, headache, nausea vomiting

Other uses – Post coital pill – 60 mg within 24 hours followed by another 60 mg 12 hours later.

Contraindications

PCOD, hepatic/renal dysfunction, cervical dysplasia, allergy to the drug and tuberculosis.

Trade names – Saheli (old name), Chhaya – supplied freely at health facilities and through ASHA.

questions.text: Paralytic ileus is a type of:
questions.solution:
Paralytic ileus is a type of adynamic obstruction.

Paralytic ileus is an adynamic obstruction in which there is a failure of transmission of peristaltic waves secondary to neuromuscular failure (i.e., in the myenteric [Auerbach’s] and submucous [Meissner’s] plexuses). Since there are no rigorous contractions, there is no colicky pain.

Clinical features :

The resultant stasis leads to the following:

  • Accumulation of fluid and gas in the bowel
  • With associated distension: marked and tympanitic
  • Vomiting (effortless)
  • Absence of bowel sounds
  • Absolute constipation
  • Paralytic ileus takes on clinical significance if any of the following are observed at 72 hours after laparotomy:
    • No return of bowel sounds on auscultation
    • No passage of flatus
  • Colicky pain is not a feature
  • Radiologically, the abdomen shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple fluid levels (if an erect film is felt necessary)

Treatment:

  • Paralytic ileus is managed with the use of nasogastric suction and restriction of oral intake until bowel sounds and the passage of flatus return.
  • Electrolyte balance must be maintained.

questions.text: All of the following are the complications of massive blood transfusion except ___________
questions.solution:
The complication of massive transfusion includes Hypothermia, not Hyperthermia.

The lethal triad of massive transfusion include: Acidosis, Hypothermia, and Coagulopathy.

Other complications from massive transfusion include:

  • Hypocalcaemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can minimize the veno-occlusive disease of liver, occurring as a side effect of alkylating agents?
questions.solution:
Defibrotide is the only FDA-approved drug for treating veno-occlusive disease. The mechanism of action has not been fully elucidated. It enhances the enzymatic activity of plasmin to hydrolyse fibrin clots. It increases tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) and thrombomodulin expression and decreases von Willebrand factor (vWF) and plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI-1) expression, thus, reducing activation of endothelial cells and increasing fibrinolysis mediated by them.

Cladribine is an antimetabolite used in the treatment of hairy cell leukaemia.

Busulfan and cyclophosphamide can worsen veno-occlusive disease of liver.

questions.text: A maximum of how many cysts is punctured in polycystic ovary syndrome during laparoscopic drilling of ovarian cysts?

Not more than four ovarian cysts are punctured/drilled per ovary in polycystic ovary syndrome. Excessive drilling may lead on to premature ovarian failure.

Surgery restores endocrine milieu and improves fertility for a year or so. Ovulation occurs in 80–90% and pregnancy in 60–70%. Thereafter, pelvic adhesions caused by surgery may again reduce fertility rate.

Indications of surgery:

  • Failed medical therapy
  • Hyper stimulation occurs
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

questions.text:
ABG analysis of a patient reveals the findings given below. Which of the following is the most likely metabolic abnormality in this patient?

Blood pH: 7.50

PaCO2: 36 mmHg

HCO3-: 30 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of metabolic alkalosis and respiratory alkalosis.

Since both the pH and bicarbonate are increased it is a case of metabolic alkalosis. Also, in the case of metabolic alkalosis, respiratory compensation includes a rise in PaCO2. But in this case, it is less than expected, which suggests concomitant respiratory alkalosis.

Finding the primary abnormality

pH = 7.50 Normal = (7.35 – 7.45) Increased
paCO2 = 36 Normal = (35 – 45) Normal
HCO3- = 30 Normal = (22 – 28) Increased

These values clearly suggest metabolic alkalosis.

Calculating the compensation

In metabolic alkalosis, the predicted PaCO2 after compensation should be [HCO3-] + 15.

So PaCO2 level after compensation should be [30] + [15] = 45 mmHg. However, PaCO2 levels are 36 mmHg, which is far lower than the expected value. This indicates that there is a component of respiratory alkalosis in this patient as well. 

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: Extra mammary intraepidermal adenocarcinoma is commonly seen in the:
questions.solution:
Extramammary Paget's disease ( intraepidermal adenocarcinoma )  arises most commonly in postmenopausal women and on the vulva.

Paget’s disease:

  • Most commonly seen in areas of high density of apocrine sweat glands and in elderly females.
  • These can develop into an invasive cancer of the underlying apocrine glands.
  • Symptom: Intractable itching
  • Appearance: Eczematous, well-demarcated plaque, with occasional ulceration and scaling .
  • Histology: Detection of Paget cells (large, vacuolated cytoplasm with eccentric nuclei) confirms the diagnosis.
    • The cells stain positively for periodic acid-Schiff, mucicarmine, Alcian blue, and cytokeratin 7.
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy

Note:

  • Most common site of extramammary Paget’s disease – Anogenital region > Axilla > Eyelid
  • Perianal Paget’s disease is usually associated with underlying visceral malignancy, most commonly colorectal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: According to DSM-V, how long should symptoms be present before a diagnosis of hypomania?
questions.solution:
Symptoms must be present for at least 4 consecutive days for a diagnosis of hypomania to be made.

DSM-V criteria for Hypomania:

  • Distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated/irritable mood, abnormally and persistently increased activity/energy, lasting for at least 4 consecutive days.
  • During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy and activity, three or more of the following symptoms have been present to a significant degree:
  1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
  2. Decreased need for sleep
  3. More talkative than usual
  4. Flight of ideas
  5. Distractibility
  6. Increase in goal-oriented activity or psychomotor agitation
  7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences

The episode must not be severe enough to cause marked impairment in social/occupational functioning or necessitate hospitalization.

Related Pearl: Mania Vs Hypomania

Mania Hypomania
Symptoms for at least 1 week Symptoms for at least 4 days
Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning No impairment in social or occupational functioning
May need hospitalization Doesn't need hospitalization

questions.text: The image below shows X-rays of a patient with chronic osteomyelitis. The structure marked as ‘3’ in the given image denotes _______.

  3. Sequestrum is a piece of devitalized bone that has been separated from its surrounding bone during the process of necrosis.

questions.text: A patient presented with a passage of blood instead of urine and severe abdominal pain. Laboratory examination revealed normo-macrocytic anemia.  On further evaluation, mutation of the PIGA gene was seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

It is a disease that results from acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA), which is required for the synthesis of phosphatidylinositol glycan (PIG).

It is a chronic hemolytic anemia that is characterized by intravascular hemolysis. Apart from hemolysis, other features like pancytopenia and venous thrombosis are also seen. Patients may present with the passage of blood instead of urine, recurrent abdominal pain, and anemia which is normo-macrocytic.

Other options:

Option A: Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by mutations that most frequently involve ankyrin, band 3, or spectrin (i.e. inherited defects in the membrane skeleton). It is characterized by jaundice, enlarged spleen, and gallstones.

Option C: Sickle cell anemia is caused by a mutation in β-globin that creates sickle hemoglobin (HbS). It is characterized by hemolytic anemia, reticulocytosis, hyperbilirubinemia, hand-foot syndrome, acute chest syndrome (fever, cough, and chest pain), and priapism.

Option D: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency results from abnormalities affecting the G6PD enzyme. This leaves red cells vulnerable to oxidative injury and hemolysis. They mainly present with hemolytic anemia and neonatal jaundice in a few cases.

Related Pearl: Classification of Hemolytic Anemias

Hemolytic anemias can be classified in 2 ways:

1. Based on the type of defect:

Type  Intracorpuscular Defects Extracorpuscular Factors
Hereditary

Hemoglobinopathies

Enzymopathies

Membrane-cytoskeletal defects

 Familial (atypical) hemolytic uremic syndrome
Acquired Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Mechanical destruction (microangiopathic)

Toxic agents

Drugs

Infectious

Autoimmune

2. Based on the sites of hemolysis:

Intravascular hemolysis:

  • Mechanical injury
    • Trauma caused by cardiac valves 
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura) 
    • Repetitive physical trauma
  • Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)
    • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- ABO incompatibility
    • Transfusion reaction  
    • Drug-induced 
  • Infections of red blood cells 
    • Malaria
    • Babesiosis
  • Exogenous toxic factors - clostridial sepsis

Extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- Rh incompatibility

Both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis:

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
