questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for depolarization of the glomus cells in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Reduced efflux of potassium ions and influx of calcium ions are responsible for the depolarization of glomus cells in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors.

Glomus cells have oxygen sensing potassium channels which are inactivated by decreasing PO2. Inactivation of these channels leads to depolarisation of the glomus cells and excitation of the afferent nerve endings in the peripheral chemoreceptors.

questions.text: What is the specific reversal agent for dabigatran?
questions.solution:
Idarucizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment (Fab) that binds to dabigatran and its acyl-glucuronide metabolites with higher affinity than the binding affinity of dabigatran to thrombin.

Other options:

  • Bezlotoxumab is a monoclonal antibody against Clostridium difficile toxin B that neutralizes the toxin after binding it. It is indicated for reducing recurrence of C. difficile infections in high-risk patients.
  • Lebrikizumab is an antibody against interleukin 13, which is indicated in the management of asthma.
  • Reslizumab is a monoclonal antibody against interleukin 5 that in approved for use in asthma.

Specific reversal agents for anticoagulants:

  • Heparin: protamine sulfate
  • Warfarin: vitamin K
  • Rivaroxaban and other oral Xa inhibitors: andexanet alfa
  • Dabigatran: idarucizumab

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as Stage X1A in the WHO classification of vitamin A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Stage X1A refers to Conjunctival xerosis in the WHO classification of vitamin A deficiency.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration

X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: The image given below is a characteristic finding of:
questions.solution:
The image shows a teardrop bladder (pear-shaped bladder) characteristically seen in pelvic hematoma. It is also seen in pelvic lipomatosis,  pelvic abscess, bilateral pelvic lymphadenopathy, and intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

A pear-shaped (or teardrop-shaped) bladder is one whose normal round or ovoid shape has been extrinsically compressed to resemble a pear. The pear may be inverted or upright, depending on how the excess pelvic tissue compresses the bladder.

Other important radiological appearances in urogenital system:

  • Fir tree/pine tree/Christmas tree bladder: Neurogenic bladder
  • Sun-burst appearance of the bladder: Extraperitoneal bladder rupture.

  • Drooping flower appearance: Ectopic ureter

questions.text: A researcher conducts a study among smokers. He finds that 80% of the cases of lung cancer are due to cigarette smoking. This is indicative of:
questions.solution:
The study where the researcher finds that 80% of lung cancer cases are due to cigarette smoking is indicative of attributable risk.

Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease between an exposed group and an unexposed group.

It is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure. It also refers to the amount of disease that could be eliminated if the exposure is controlled or eliminated. It reflects the impact of public health programs in the prevention of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: Incidence of a disease refers to the number of new cases occurring in a population in a given period of time.

Option B: Relative risk refers to the ratio of incidence of the disease among the exposed and the incidence of disease among the unexposed population. It establishes the strength of association between the disease and the suspected causative factor.

Option D: Population attributable risk refers to the incidence of the disease in the total population minus the incidence of disease among the population unexposed to the causative factor. It indicates the incidence of disease that could be prevented in the total population if the suspected causative factor was eliminated. 

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: Which of the following pathways is implicated in the formation of diabetic cataract?
questions.solution:
The polyol pathway has been implicated in the formation of diabetic cataracts.

This pathway results in the production of fructose from glucose and sorbitol is formed as an intermediate. In diabetics, its activity is increased due to increased glucose levels. Sorbitol accumulates in the lens, causing osmotic damage and cataract.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with splenomegaly and pancytopenia.  Suspecting a hematological malignancy, you prepare a peripheral blood smear, which revealed the findings shown in the given image. These cells were also found to be annexin A1 positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows abnormal B cells with fine hair-like cytoplasmic projections characteristic of hairy cell leukemia.

Hairy cell leukemia:

  • It is associated with BRAF mutations.
  • It mainly occurs in older males.
  • Splenomegaly is the most common physical finding. 
  • It is extremely sensitive to chemotherapeutic agents.
  • Overall prognosis is excellent.
  • Pathology:
    • Hairy cell leukemia is limited to the red pulp of the spleen, which is heavily infiltrated. This leads to the obliteration of white pulp and a beefy red gross appearance.
    • Hairy cells can be identified in the peripheral blood smear.
    • Pancytopenia results from marrow infiltration and splenic sequestration.
    • A "dry tap" is common on aspiration.
    • Detection of annexin A1 in bone marrow specimens has been shown to have 100% sensitivity and specificity in differentiating hairy cell leukemia from other B-cell malignancies.
    • Trephine biopsy: Leukemic cells have a nucleus surrounded by a cytoplasmic halo giving them a fried-egg appearance.
    • CD11c, CD25, and CD103 are the characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic markers.
    • Cells test positive for pan-B-cell markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22.
    • Cells stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP).

The image given below shows small cells with clear cytoplasm and a round central nucleus—fried-egg appearance.

Option A - Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a peripheral B-cell neoplasm. The classical immunophenotypic feature of CLL is CD19+, CD20+, CD23+, and CD5+. It also shows BCL2 positivity.

The image shows small round lymphocytes and smudge cells seen in CLL.

Option B: Follicular lymphoma is characterized by t(14;18). Tumor cells are positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL2 and negative for CD5. Histopathology of the enlarged nodes shows nodular expansion of tumor cells, composed of small cells with cleaved nuclei (centrocytes) and larger cells with more cytoplasm (centroblasts).

The following image shows a lymph node biopsy in follicular lymphoma:

Option C: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by t(9;22), a translocation between the BCR and ABL genes that leads to the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome. This results in the activation of tyrosine kinase, which causes abnormal cellular proliferation.

The image below shows peripheral smear findings of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) with neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

Related Pearl: Origin of leukemia / lymphoma and their immunophenotypes

B cell precursors Derived lymphomas/leukemia Immunophenotype
Pro-B cell Pro-B cell ALL CD34, CD19, CD79a

questions.text: Community X has 30% of the population who are below 15 years of age and 10% of the population over 65 years. The dependency ratio here would be:
questions.solution:
Total dependency ratio = 100* (Total population below 15 years and above 65 years)/(Total population in the age group of 15 – 64).

Here, the dependency ratio would be 100* (30% + 10%)/60% = 66.6%.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about aldesleukin?

choices.text: Acts as a ligand for TLR-7
Used for treatment of metastatic RCC
Combination of recombinant IL-2 and diphtheria toxin
It is a BCR/ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor

questions.solution:
Aldesleukin is the recombinant interleukin-2 preparation that acts as the IL-2 agonist and is approved for use in metastatic melanoma and metastatic renal-cell cancer.

Other options:

  • Denileukin diftitox is an immunotoxin made from the recombinant combination of IL-2 and the catalytically active fragment of diphtheria toxin. It is approved for use in cutaneous T cell lymphoma
  • Imatinib and nilotinib is a BCR/ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor
  • Imiquimod acts as a ligand for Toll like receptor (TLR) 7

questions.text: For a given molecular size, which of the following is more readily filtered at the glomerulus?
questions.solution:
For a given molecular size, filtration at the glomerular membrane is as follows - positive charge > neutral/hydrophobic/lipophilic > negative charge.

The reason for this selectivity is that the glomerular filtration membrane has negatively charged proteoglycans and hence negatively charged molecules are repulsed.

Clinical relevance – The negative charge of the glomerular membrane is why negatively charged albumin is not filtered, though its size of 6nm is less than the glomerular pore size of 8 nm.

questions.text: Theophylline clearance can be decreased due to:
questions.solution:
Co-administration of ciprofloxacin decreases the clearance of theophylline.

Factors increasing clearance of theophylline:

  • Enzyme induction (CYP1A2) by co-administered drugs
  • Smoking tobacco/marijuana by CYP1A2 induction
  • High-protein, low carbohydrate diet
  • Barbecued meat
  • Childhood

Factors decreasing clearance of theophylline, thus causing toxicity:

  • Enzyme inhibition (CYP1A2) by co-administered drugs such as ciprofloxacin
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Liver disease
  • Pneumonia
  • Viral infection and vaccination
  • High-carbohydrate diet

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Revised Atlanta classification is used for assessing severity of acute pancreatitis.

Atlanta classification:

Mild Acute Pancreatitis

  • No organ failure
  • No local or systemic complications

Moderately Severe Acute Pancreatitis

  • Transient organ failure (<48 hours) and/or
  • Local or systemic complications without persistent organ failure

Severe Acute Pancreatitis

  • Persistent organ failure (>48 hours)–single organ or multiorgan

Other options:

Child Pugh classification: is used for chronic liver disease

PELD Score: Paediatric End Stage Liver Disease Score

KDRI Score: Kidney Donor Risk Index Score

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:
    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
    • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
    • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Age > 60 years
    • Pleural effusion
      One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.
  • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
    If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:
    • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
    • Normal hematocrit
    • Normal serum creatinine

  • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)
    • A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe
    • Can be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age
  • Ranson’s score
  • Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe
  • Atlanta classification

questions.text: An elderly woman underwent total hip replacement surgery 4 days back. She is advised to wear compression stockings for the prevention of a particular condition.  Which of the following is true regarding this particular condition?

choices.text: Clinical assessment is reliable in establishing the diagnosis
Pain and swelling in the calf are most common presentations
Inflammatory bowel disease is protective against developing this condition

questions.solution:
The patient is provided with a pair of compression stockings to prevent the occurrence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Pain and swelling in the calf are the most common presentations of DVT. 

Clinical features of DVT include:

  • Fever 
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf.
  • Positive Homan’s, Mose’s, or Neuhof’s signs.
  • Inverted champagne bottle sign
  • Features of pulmonary embolism such as pulmonary hypertension, dyspnea ad pleuritic chest pain
  • It may be asymptomatic

Most cases of DVT are unilateral. Bilateral cases are seen in 30% of individuals. DVT commonly occurs in pelvis veins and leg veins such as femoral and popliteal veins (common on the left side). Inflammatory bowel disease is a risk factor for the development of DVT. 

The clinical examination may be unreliable in establishing the diagnosis. Venous duplex ultrasound is commonly performed to look for evidence of thrombosis throughout the deep or superficial venous system.  Ascending venography may be rarely required unless thrombolysis is being considered. MR venography may also be used. In the case of a pulmonary embolus, a definitive diagnosis can be done by CT pulmonary angiogram.

Treatment includes:

  • Rest, the elevation of the limb, bandaging the entire limb with a crepe bandage
  • Anticoagulants - heparin/low molecular weight heparin, warfarin, phenindione
  • Thrombolysis, endovenous thrombectomy, and stenting to prevent post-thrombotic syndrome
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

Mechanical prophylaxis
Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) - Enoxaparin

Fondaparinux

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

Apixaban

Rivaroxaban 

  Oral factor Xa inhibitors

Unfractionated heparin (UFH)

Prevents action of factors VIII - XII and production of thrombin/fibrin.

Used in renal insufficiency

Warfarin

Inhibits hepatic production of factors II, VII, IX and X

questions.text: The most common cause of death in battered baby syndrome is:
questions.solution:
The most common cause of death in battered baby syndrome is head injury followed by rupture of abdominal organ.

The classic head injury associated with battered children is subdural hematoma.

questions.text: According to the FIGO classification, tumour of the ovary involving the inguinal lymph nodes is classified under what stage?
questions.solution:
Ovarian tumour involving the inguinal lymph nodes comes under stage IVb according to the FIGO classification.

      • C3: malignant ascites

questions.text: Choose the correct statement about the equilibrium state:

choices.text: The rate constants become equal to each other
Forward and backward reaction rates are equal
Forward and backward reaction rates equal zero

questions.solution:
At equilibrium, forward and backward reaction rates are equal and there is no change in the concentration of substrates and products.

The rate constants of the forward and backward reactions do not change. The equilibrium constant, defined as the ratio of the rate constants, also doesn’t change. The equilibrium constant can be calculated as follows:

For the reaction mA + nB ⇌ P

At equilibrium,

Rate of the forward reaction = Rate of the backward reaction

K1[A]m[B]n = K2[P], where K1 and K2 are the rate constants of the forward and backward reactions respectively

Equilibrium constant = K1/K2 = [P]/[A]m[B]n

questions.text: The gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of hepatitis C infection is?
questions.solution:
Assays for HCV RNA are the most sensitive tests for HCV infection and represent the “gold standard” in establishing a diagnosis of hepatitis C.

HCV RNA

  • Elevated even before acute increase in aminotransferase levels
  • It appears before anti-HCV in acute hepatitis C patients.
  • It remains detectable indefinitely.
  • Determination of HCV RNA level is not a reliable marker of disease severity or prognosis.

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked as "A" in the image below, at the interphalangeal joint?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked as A in the above image is Lumbricals.

Lumbricals:

  • Lumbricals are intrinsic muscles of the hand that flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints.
  • They originate from Flexor digitorum profundus.
  • L1 and L2 (lateral) are unipennate, supplied by the Median nerve.
  • L3 and L4 (medial) are bipinnate, supplied by the Ulnar nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle lengthens and affects the tension  of the vocal cords in the given diagram?
questions.solution:
The Cricothyroid muscle lengthens and affects the tension in the vocal cords - marked as D.

Other options:

A: Marks the lateral cricoarytenoids muscle. Brings the tips of the vocal processes together, closing the ligamentous part of the rima glottidis, an action known as medial compression. Contraction of lateral cricoarytenoid also results in shortening and relaxing of the vocal folds.

B: Marks the transverse arytenoid muscle: pulls the arytenoid cartilages towards each other, closing the posterior, intercartilaginous, part of the rima glottidis, termed adductive tensing by phoneticians.

C: The posterior cricoarytenoids are responsible for the abduction of the vocal cords.

questions.text: A child knows about her full name, age and gender but unable to tell a story. What will be the child’s age if her development is normal?
questions.solution:
A child knows about her full name, age, and gender at 3 years.

A child can tell stories by the age of 4. Hence, the child’s age in the given context will be 3 years.

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental milestones 

At 1 year

  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months

At 2 years

  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories

At 3 years

  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children

At 4 years

  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
 At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: Small to medium sized sterile vegetations attached on either side of the valve leaflets and an association with systemic lupus erythematosus is found in:
questions.solution:
Libman-Sacks endocarditis is characterized by the presence of sterile vegetations on the valves of patients with systemic lupus erythematosus.

The lesions develop as a consequence of immune complex deposition. Subsequent fibrosis and serious deformity can result in lesions that resemble chronic rheumatic heart disease.

These can occur anywhere on the valve surface, on the cords, or on the atrial or ventricular endocardium.

questions.text: Smoky green urine is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Smoky green urine is a feature of phenol/carbolic acid poisoning because of oxidation of its metabolic end products hydroquinone and pyrocatechol. These products turn urine olive green or brown on standing and the phenomenon is called carboluria.

Carbolic acid or phenol is an organic acid that is used as a disinfectant and solvent. It has a characteristic phenolic odor. Poisoning by carbolic acid is called carbolism.

On exposure to the skin, carbolic acid coagulates the proteins and causes the formation of an eschar that will come off as slough later. It can damage the nerves and cause tingling and numbness.

On ingestion, a burning sensation may be felt, along with nausea and vomiting. Vomiting puts the patient at risk of aspiration pneumonia. The acid can also cause pulmonary and laryngeal edema, leading to difficulty breathing, and ultimately respiratory failure. Systemic features include headache, dizziness, syncope, and even coma.

Diagnosis of carbolic acid poisoning can be made by adding a few drops of 10% ferric chloride to the patient's urine sample. If the sample turns violet or blue, it indicates the presence of phenolic compounds. The urine sample would also reduce Benedict's and Fehling's solutions.

Treatment involves removing contaminated clothing and washing the skin. If the patient has ingested the poison, cautious gastric lavage with 20% alcohol, glycerol, or vegetable oil should be carried out. MgSO4 or liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach to remove surface phenol and prevent deep penetration. Parenteral saline can also be administered to correct the circulatory depression, dilute the carbolic acid content of the blood, and promote its excretion. Hemodialysis can be carried out if there is renal failure.

Other options: 

Option B: Smoky stool syndrome/luminescent stool is a feature of phosphorous poisoning. 

Option C and D: Arsenic and mercury poisoning are not associated with green urine. See pearls #2099 and #2100.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: All of the following are calcineurin inhibitors except:
questions.solution:
Sirolimus inhibits the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) leading to inhibition of lymphocyte growth and differentiation. While it is less nephrotoxic, it is associated with suppressive effects on the bone marrow, decreased wound healing, and hyperlipidaemia.

Cyclosporine A and Tacrolimus (also known as fujimycin or FK-506) are calcineurin inhibitors.

Note:

  • Cyclosporine is a cyclic polypeptide produced by the fungus Beauveria nivea.
  • Tacrolimus is a macrolide antibiotic produced by Streptomyces tsukubaensis.
  • Sirolimus (rapamycin) is a macrocyclic lactone produced by Streptomyces hygroscopicus.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs act predominantly by inhibiting N type Calcium channels?
questions.solution:
Gabapentin acts predominantly by inhibiting N type calcium channels, however it is interesting to note that it can inhibit L, N and P/Q type calcium channels.

Verapamil, diltiazem, and dihydropyridines block L-type calcium channels by binding to alpha 1 subunit. Lercanidipine blocks both L and T type calcium channels significantly.

  • L-type calcium channels consist of α1, α2, δ, and β subunits.
  • Verapamil and diltiazem also bind to alpha 1 subunit to another closely related identical site.
  • Verapamil is a congener of papaverine.
  • Papaverine is a vasodilator alkaloid found in the opium poppy.
  • Verapamil was the first clinically used calcium channel blocker.

Related Pearl: Types of calcium channels and their blockers

Type of Calcium Channel Blockers
L type Verapamil, diltiazem, dihydropyridines
T type Flunarizine, ethosuximide, mibefradil
N type Gabapentin, ziconotide
P/Q type Omega agatoxin IVa
R type SNX-482, Omega agatoxin IIIa

questions.text: A milk sample received by health care workers is to undergo a quality checking process. All the following tests can be used to check the efficiency of pasteurization, except:
questions.solution:
All the given tests can be used to check the efficiency of pasteurization except the methylene blue reduction test.

Methylene blue reduction test is an indirect method for the detection of microorganisms in milk. The test is carried out on the milk accepted for pasteurization to check for gross contamination, and not to check the efficiency of pasteurization.

Tests to check the efficiency of pasteurization:

  • Phosphatase test
  • Standard plate count
  • Coliform count

Methods of pasteurization:

  • Holder/Vat method: 63-66 °C for 30 minutes
  • HTST method (High temp short time): 72°C for 15 seconds
  • UHT method (Ultra-high temp): 125 °C for a few seconds

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Cushing’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Hyperglycemia and not hypoglycemia are associated with Cushing’s syndrome.

Clinical features of Cushing’s syndrome include:

  • Obesity or weight gain (>115% ideal body weight) – Most common
  • Thin skin
  • Moon facies
  • Hypertension
  • Purple striae
  • Hirsutism
  • Menstrual disorders (usually amenorrhea)
  • Abnormal glucose tolerance
  • Impotence
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Acne, bruising
  • Osteoporosis
  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
  • Diabetes mellitus

questions.text: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasms with arching of his back, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. Microscopy of the specimen revealed a gram-positive, rod-shaped bacillus. Which of the following describes the characteristics of the spores produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative organism based on the given clinical scenario is Clostridium tetani. It is a gram-positive, anaerobic, rod-shaped bacillus with spores that are spherical and terminally located.

Clostridium tetani has spherical and terminal spores, giving it a drumstick appearance.

  • The genus Clostridium consists of gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming bacilli.
  • The spores are wider than the bacillary bodies, giving the bacillus a swollen appearance, resembling a spindle. Hence, the name Clostridium.

Classification of Clostridium based on the shape and position of spores:

  • Central or Subterminal:  Clostridium bifermentans, Clostridium perfringens, Clostridium novyi, and Clostridium botulinum
  • Oval and terminal (tennis racket shaped ): Clostridium tertium and Clostridium difficile
  • Spherical and terminal (drumstick appearance): Clostridium tetani.

The incubation period of C. tetani ranges from 6-12 days. It produces an exotoxin tetanospasmin which causes muscle spasms usually involving the area of injury first and then the muscles of the jaw causing trismus or lockjaw. Gradually, other voluntary muscles become involved, resulting in tonic spasms. Any external stimulus can precipitate a tetanic generalized muscle spasm. The patient is conscious but may be in pain. Death usually results from respiratory paralysis.

The image given below shows spherical and terminal spores of C. tetani:

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has a predominant autosomal recessive inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in the CFTR gene (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene) encoding the CF transmembrane regulator.

The principal defect is of chloride ion transport, resulting in high salt concentrations in sweat and in viscous luminal secretions in respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.

Option B: Familial hypercholesterolemia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the gene encoding the LDL receptor.

Option C: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by mutations disrupting the function of the dystrophin gene located on the short arm of the X chromosome (Xp21).

Option D: Hereditary spherocytosis is usually transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait and rarely as autosomal recessive. Mutations that cause hereditary spherocytosis most frequently involve ankyrin, band 3, or spectrin.

(Hardinge) Hunter's syndrome, Hemophilia A and B
(Rose) Rickets
(College) Chronic granulomatous disease
(All) Alport syndrome (common inheritance pattern)
(Girls) G-6-PD deficiency
(Children) Type X Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease
(Don’t) Duchenne muscular dystrophy, Diabetes insipidus
 
(Care) Color blindness
 
(About) Agammaglobulinemia, Alport syndrome, Ocular albinism
 
(Foolish) Fabry disease
  
(Words) Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome
  
Other conditions: Menke's disease, Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency

questions.text: The finding of uteroplacental apoplexy is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Uteroplacental apoplexy is also known as Couvelaire uterus and is associated with severe concealed abruptio placenta.

It refers to a massive intravasation of blood into the uterine musculature extending up to the serous coat. The condition is observed on laparotomy but doesn’t require hysterectomy as it rarely interferes with uterine contractions.

Complications of this condition include the following:

  • Acute cortical/tubular necrosis in the kidney due to intra-renal vasospasm secondary to massive hemorrhage
  • Blood in the peritoneal cavity and broad ligament hematoma
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation with consumption coagulopathy and hypofibrinogenemia

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about sprengel deformity?

choices.text: It is failure of scapula to descend from the cervical spine
Surgery is performed after 10 years of age

questions.solution:
Surgery for Sprengel deformity is best performed before the age of 6 yrs.

Sprengel deformity:

  • The child has obvious asymmetry of the shoulders, with elevation and underdevelopment of the affected side.
  • The scapula is abnormally small and too high.
  • Shoulder movements may be restricted and on abduction or elevation the scapula moves very little or not at all.
  • May be associated with other defects of the cervical spine e.g. Klippel–Feil syndrome
  • Represents a failure of scapular descent from the cervical spine
  • Treatment is required only if shoulder movements are severely limited or if the deformity is particularly unsightly. Operation is best performed before the age of 6 years.

questions.text: Vidian neurectomy is done in a case of:
questions.solution:
Vidian neurectomy i.e. sectioning of parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to nose is done in case of vasomotor rhinitis.

Young’s operation - Both the nostrils are closed completely just within the nasal vestibule by raising flaps. They are opened after 6 months or later. In these cases, mucosa may revert to normal and crusting reduced.

Modified Young’s operation- aims at partially closing the nostrils. Result is same as Young’s operation.

Option A: Submucous resection operation and septoplasty are done for DNS.

Option C: Allergic rhinitis is only managed medically.

questions.text: Which of the following color coding is used for nitrous oxide cylinder?
questions.solution:
Blue cylinders are used to store nitrous oxide.

Maximum pressure in the nitrous oxide cylinder is around 745 psig.

Critical temperature of nitrous oxide is 36.5oC, hence it is present in liquid form at room temperature.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of medical gas cylinders

questions.text: The following diagram charts the HDL values in a given population. What is the statistical diagram used here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Frequency polygons.

Frequency polygons:

  • Frequency polygons are used for ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of the condition depicted below?

choices.text: Adrenal glands are normal in position

questions.solution:
The above image shows a horseshoe kidney. Fused portion lies adjacent to the L3 or L4 vertebra just below the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery. Ascent of the fused kidneys is prevented by the inferior mesenteric artery.

Horseshoe kidney:

  • 2:1 male predominance
  • More commonly found in patients with sacral agenesis, high cloacas, and Turner syndrome
  • Higher risk of renal cell carcinoma and Wilms tumor
  • Fused portion lies adjacent to the L3 or L4 vertebra just below the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery. Ascent of the fused kidneys is prevented by the inferior mesenteric artery.
  • Increases the vulnerability to develop into a diseased condition, possibly because the ureters are angulated causing urinary stasis, infection, and nephrolithiasis.
  • Radiological diagnosis is by intravenous pyelogram which shows "flower vase" sign or "hand shake" sign.
  • Heminephrectomy is not usually indicated in horseshoe kidney because it can result in the devascularization of the lower ends of both kidneys. This happens because of the unpredictable blood supply of the horseshoe from nearby major vessels.
  • Division of relatively avascular isthmus between the kidneys is only indicated in the course of surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm.

IVP showing horseshoe kidney:

questions.text: A bullet that causes fire on hitting the target is:
questions.solution:
Incendiary bullets are those filled with explosive (e.g. white phosphorus) at the front end that causes fire on hitting the target.

Frangible bullets are those which are designed to disintegrate into tiny fragments upon target impact.

Dumdum bullets are also called expanding bullets. The tips of these bullets are designed to burst or expand into fragments on impact causing damage over a larger area.

Tandem bullet is a phenomenon seen when two bullets are fired in one shot with one lying right behind the other. It occurs in old, dirty or country firearms. Sometimes an ejected bullet may get lodged in the barrel and comes out when the next shot is fired – in tandem with that bullet.

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the PALM-COEIN acronym used to classify abnormal uterine bleeding?
questions.solution: Endometriosis is not a part of the PALM-COEIN acronym used to classify the causes of abnormal uterine bleeding. The E in PALM-COEIN stands for endometrial causes.

questions.text: The most common period of HIV infection in the newborn is _______
questions.solution:
The most common period of HIV infection in an infant is during delivery - intrapartum period

HIV transmission in an infant:

  • In utero (During pregnancy)
  • During delivery (Intrapartum) Most common
  • After birth by breast feeding - Least common

Risk factors for vertical transmission:

  • High maternal viremia (most important)
  • Preterm delivery (<34 weeks)
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Prolonged rupture of membranes (>4 hours)
  • Low birth weight
  • Low maternal CD4 count

Note: The mechanism of perinatal transmission appears to be mucosal exposure to infected blood and cervicovaginal secretions in the birth canal. The intrauterine contractions during active labor/delivery could also increase the risk of late micro transfusions.

questions.text: You are a researcher studying the effects of acetylcholine on the heart and the muscarinic receptor M2 through which its actions are mediated. Which of the following change is mediated by muscarinic receptor subtype M2?
questions.solution:
The reduction of cAMP is mediated by the activation of the muscarinic receptor M2. 

Muscarinic receptors are G-protein coupled receptors and consist of five subtypes: M1, M2, M3, M4 and M5. 

M2 is a muscarinic cholinergic receptor that is located in the heart. When an agonist binds to the receptor, it opens K+ channels and causes inhibition of adenyl cyclase. This in turn inhibits the activation of cAMP. M4 subtype acts by the same mechanism but is located in the central nervous system. 

M1 is present in autonomic ganglia while glands and smooth muscles contain the M3 subtype. M5 is also located in the central nervous system. These subtypes act by increasing the inositol triphosphate (IP3) and Diacylglycerol (DAG)

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: Lofgren’s syndrome includes:
questions.solution:
Lofgren’s syndrome is an acute presentation of sarcoidosis, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum, and bilateral hilar adenopathy. It has a good prognosis, with > 90% of patients experiencing disease resolution within 2 years.

Heerfordt–Waldenström syndrome or uveoparotid fever is a variant of sarcoidosis, comprising of:

  • Fever
  • Parotid enlargement
  • Facial palsy
  • Ocular involvement (anterior uveitis)

Other options:

  • Erythema marginatum: is a feature of acute rheumatic fever.
  • Erythema induratum (Bazin’s disease): is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis (tuberculid).
  • HLA B27 positivity is a feature of Reiter’s syndrome (HLA-DRB1*03 is positive in Lofgren’s syndrome)

questions.text: A 50-year-old male diabetic with CCF under treatment was started. A week later, he complained of a yellow hue in his vision. He was treated for tuberculosis 8 months back. What can be the probable cause(s) for this symptom?
questions.solution:
Yellowing of vision (xanthopsia) can be an early indication of digoxin toxicity.

It can also be an adverse effect of thiazide diuretics (chlorthalidone, hydrochlorothiazide, indapamide). Sildenafil use can characteristically lead to cyanopsia.

Antitubercular drug, ethambutol: can cause retrobulbar neuritis and red-green colour blindness

Note: Hydrochlorothiazide can cause hypokalaemia (especially in the initial 2 to 3 weeks, and thus warrants monitoring during that period). Hypokalaemia, hypercalcemia, hypernatremia and hypomagnesemia can precipitate digitalis toxicity.

Also, calcium administration in a patient with digitalis toxicity is avoided due to a risk of an irreversible state of global myocardial contraction (stone heart syndrome).

questions.text: How are magnitude of stimulus felt and intensity of stimulus applied related according to the Weber-Fechner law?
questions.solution:
According to the Weber-Fechner law, the magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the logarithm of the applied stimulus intensity.

Other important laws in neurophysiology:

  • Bell Magendie law- The anterior or ventral roots of the spinal nerves are motor and the posterior or dorsal nerve roots are sensory.
  • Law of projection- Stimulation of a sensory system at any point central to sensory organs produces a sensation that is projected at the periphery and not at the point of stimulation.

questions.text: In which of the following methods of gene transfer, does a phage carries a section of DNA from one bacterium to the other?
questions.solution:
Transduction is the transfer of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage.

  • Conjugation is a method of gene transfer in bacteria which involves the transfer of plasmids. A male or donor bacterium makes physical contact with a female or recipient bacterium and transfers the genetic elements into it.
  • Transformation involves direct uptake of naked DNA by the recipient cell from the environment.
  • Transposition is the transfer of DNA material from chromosomal DNA to plasmid DNA and back.

Note:

  • Transcription: Process by which mRNA is produced from DNA.
  • Translation: Process by which proteins are produced from mRNA.

questions.text: Unidextrous reach is seen at what age?
questions.solution:
Unidextrous reach at 6 months and Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months. Immature pincer grasp is seen at 9 months.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of POEMS syndrome?
questions.solution:
Polymyopathy is not a feature of POEMS Syndrome.

POEMS Syndrome consists of:

  • Polyneuropathy
  • Organomegaly (splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, or lymphadenopathy)
  • Endocrinopathy (adrenal, thyroid, pituitary, gonadal, parathyroid, and pancreatic)
  • Monoclonal gammopathy
  • Skin changes syndrome (hyperpigmentation, hypertrichosis, glomeruloid haemangiomata, plethora, acrocyanosis, flushing, and white nails)

questions.text: Which is the most sensitive investigation for the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in pregnant women and children?
questions.solution:
MRI scans have a reported sensitivity of 100% and specificity of 100% for detecting pheochromocytoma because these tumors have a characteristic appearance on T2-weighted images or after gadolinium.

MRI is also the study of choice in pregnant women as there is no risk of radiation exposure.

Metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) is taken up and concentrated by vesicles in the adrenal medullar cells because its structure is similar to norepinephrine. Normal adrenal medullary tissue does not take up appreciable MIBG. 131I-radiolabeled MIBG is, therefore, useful for localizing pheochromocytomas especially those in ectopic positions. This test has a reported sensitivity of 77% to 89% and specificity ranging from 88% to 100%.

Note: Pheochromocytomas are diagnosed by testing 24-hour urine samples for catecholamines and their metabolites and by determining plasma metanephrine levels. Radiologic studies are useful to localize tumors and to assess the extent of spread once the diagnosis has been made with biochemical tests.

However out of the given options, MRI is the best possible answer.

questions.text: Hypercalcemia is caused due to:
questions.solution:
Sarcoidosis can cause hypercalcemia. Vitamin D intoxication also leads to hypercalcemia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypercalcemia

  • Parathyroid-Related
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism
      • Adenoma(s)
      • Multiple endocrine neoplasia
      • Carcinoma
    • Lithium therapy
    • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia
  • Malignancy-Related
    • Solid tumour with metastases (breast)
    • Solid tumour with humoral mediation of hypercalcemia (lung, kidney)
    • Hematologic malignancies (multiple myeloma, lymphoma, leukemia)
  • Vitamin D–Related
    • Vitamin D intoxication
    • ↑ 1,25(OH)2D :
      • Sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases
      • Impaired 1,25(OH)2D metabolism due to 24-hydroxylase deficiency
    • Associated with high bone turnover
      • Hyperthyroidism
      • Immobilization
      • Thiazides
      • Vitamin A intoxication
      • Fat necrosis
    • Associated with renal failure
      • Severe secondary hyperparathyroidism
      • Aluminium intoxication
      • Milk-alkali syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is a type I hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Casoni’s test is a type I hypersensitivity reaction used in the diagnosis of hydatid disease.

  • It involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 ml of sterilized fluid from hydatid cysts/human cyst and sterilized by Seitz filtration on the forearm and an equal volume of saline injected on the other forearm.
  • Observations are made for next 30 mins and after 1 to 2 days.
  • A wheal response occurring at the injection site within 20 minutes is considered positive.

Cell-mediated or type IV type of hypersensitivity reaction is a delayed hypersensitivity.

  • In the tuberculin skin test, the indurated skin rash is caused by CD4-positive helper T cells and macrophages that are attracted to the injection site.
  • The Frei test is done to identify lymphogranuloma venereum. Antigen made from sterile pus aspirated from previously unruptured abscesses produced a reaction in patients with lymphogranuloma inguinale when injected intradermally.
  • Montenegro test is a delayed hypersensitivity test for cutaneous leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A 30 year old man comes with the complaints of difficulty in swallowing and food getting stuck in his throat. He also gives a history of atopic dermatitis. The endoscopic finding of the patient is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given endoscopic image shows multiple esophageal rings, longitudinally oriented furrows, and punctate exudate, which are the hallmark findings in eosinophilic esophagitis.

The symptoms of food impaction and dysphagia, along with the history of atopic dermatitis also point towards the diagnosis of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Eosinophilic esophagitis:

  • Chronic immunologically mediated disorder
  • Symptoms: Adults- food impaction, dysphagia; children- feeding intolerance, GERD-like symptoms.
  • The cardinal histologic feature is epithelial infiltration by large numbers of eosinophils
  • Endoscopically evident rings in the upper and mid portions of the esophagus
  • Typically refractory to high-dose proton pump inhibitor treatment.
  • Most patients are atopic- may have atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, asthma, and peripheral eosinophilia.
  • Treatment: dietary restrictions to prevent exposure to food allergens, such as cow milk and soy products, and topical or systemic corticosteroids.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common feature of hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia is associated with constipation (and not diarrhea).

Clinical manifestations of hypercalcemia:

  • Renal colic (Stones)
  • Bone pain bone cysts (Bones)
  • Abdominal pain from peptic ulcer (Abdominal groans)
  • Constipation (Thrones)
  • Polyuria (thrones)
  • Depression (Psychic overtones)
  • Short QT interval in ECG

Mnemonic:

"Stones, bones, abdominal groans, thrones, and psychiatric overtones".

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented to the emergency department with symptoms of acute abdominal pain. Serum lipase was done and it was found to be markedly elevated. Which of the following drug is the most common cause?
questions.solution:
Based on the presenting symptoms and elevated serum lipase levels the most probable diagnosis is acute pancreatitis.

Pancreatitis is a dose-limiting side effect of Didanosine and occurs more frequently in alcoholic patients and those with hypertriglyceridemia.

Stavudine causes peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old baby was brought with complaints of fever and fast breathing. According to IMNCI, what should be the respiratory rate to diagnose this baby with pneumonia?

IMNCI: Integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness
questions.solution:
An 18-month-old baby presenting with fever and fast breathing should have a respiratory rate of >40 to be diagnosed with pneumonia according to IMNCI.

According to the IMNCI, three key clinical signs are used to assess a sick child with suspected pneumonia:

  • Respiratory rate (RR): distinguishes children who have pneumonia from those who do not. Children are classified under pneumonia if:
    • > 60 breaths per minute if age  is < 2 months 
    • > 50/min RR for infants 2 months to 12 months
    • > 40/min RR for children 12 months to 5 years of age
  • Lower chest wall indrawing refers to the indrawing of the lower chest wall with respect to the child's breathing and indicates pneumonia
  • Stridor indicates those with severe pneumonia requiring hospital admission.

The revised classification of acute respiratory infections is simplified to include only two categories of pneumonia:

  • Cough and cold, no pneumonia - requires home remedy
  • Pneumonia - with fast breathing and/or chest indrawing, which requires home therapy with oral amoxicillin.
  • Severe pneumonia - pneumonia with any general danger sign, which requires a referral and injectable therapy. 
Danger signs of severe pneumonia are: 
  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhea. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

Symptomatic intrauterine adhesions (also termed uterine synechiae) are known as Asherman syndrome. This condition occurs when the uterine cavity is obliterated by scarring due to filmy adhesions, dense bands. Endometrial damage can occur after curettage, infection due to an intrauterine device, uterine surgery, or rarely tuberculous endometritis. 

In Asherman syndrome, oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, dysmenorrhea, abortion, and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae.

Treatment involves hysteroscopic lysis of the adhesions.

questions.text: The body of the structure marked as A, belongs to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The image shows the midsagittal section of the brain. The structure marked as “A” corresponds to the Corpus callosum which is a type of Commissural fibre.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of severe aortic stenosis presents with haematochezia of sudden onset. On examination he was found to be pale. A colonoscopic examination revealed angiodysplastic changes in the walls of the sigmoid colon. Which among the following statements are false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is also called Heyde’s syndrome
It is associated with acquired form of von Willebrand disease
It is associated with decreased Factor VIII levels
VWF multimer levels return to normal after the stenotic valve is replaced

questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the patient described is Heyde’s syndrome. It is not associated with decreased Factor VIII levels.

In contrast to the above condition, autosomal haemophilia is a variant of von Willebrand disease (type 2N) which is associated with a marked decrease in Factor VIII levels. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

Points on Heyde's syndrome:

  • It is a rare condition which comprises of aortic stenosis with gastrointestinal bleeding, which can be attributed to angiodysplasia of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • The shear stress on the blood passing through the stenotic aortic valve leads to unfolding of VWF, making it susceptible to proteolysis. This leads to loss of large multimer forms of VWF leading to an acquired form of type 2 VWD disease.
  • The VWF multimer levels return to normal after aortic valve replacement.

questions.text: Canal of Hering is found in  _______
questions.solution:
The Canals of Hering (CoH) or intrahepatic bile ductules conduct bile from bile canaliculi to terminal bile ducts in the portal tracts.

They begin in the lobules and are lined by cholangiocytes and hepatocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following substrates combine to form argininosuccinate in the urea cycle?
questions.solution:
In the urea cycle, argininosuccinic acid is formed by the combination of L-aspartate and L-citrulline. The reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme argininosuccinate synthetase.

The deficiency of this enzyme leads to citrullinemia.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: What is the category assigned to a laceration with tear of the internal anal sphincter and no involvement of the perineal body or the anorectal mucosa?
questions.solution:
An internal anal sphincter tear without involvement of the perineal body or the anorectal mucosa is categorised as a grade 3C perineal tear.

Grades of perineal laceration:

Grade Structure involved
1 Injury only to the vaginal epithelium or the perineal skin
2 Injury to the perineal muscles sparing the anal sphincter
3

A:<50% of the EAS involvement

B: Involvement of EAS >50%

C: Both EAS and IAS are involved
4 Perineal body, entire anal sphincter complex, and anorectal mucosa involved.

questions.text: The translocation characteristic of follicular lymphoma is:
questions.solution:
Majority of the follicular lymphomas have a characteristic (14;18) translocation that fuses the BCL2 gene on chromosome 18 to the IgH locus on chromosome 14.

This chromosomal rearrangement results in the overexpression of BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to cell survival.

questions.text: “Hockey stick” or an “elbow” deformity is seen in diastolic image of transthoracic echocardiography:
questions.solution:
Mitral Stenosis

The below given image shows “Hockey stick” or “elbow” deformity seen in case of mitral stenosis usually seen in chronic rheumatic heart disease.

“Hockey stick” or an “elbow” deformity is seen in diastolic image of transthoracic echocardiography:

  • Leaflet thickening
  • Restriction of the anterior mitral valve leaflet tip
  • Doming of the body of the leaflet toward the interventricular septum.

questions.text: Which of the following lipoproteins has endogenous triacylglycerol as its predominant lipid?
questions.solution:
Endogenous triacylglycerol of hepatic origin is the predominant lipid in very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL). The triacylglycerol is transported to extrahepatic tissues.

Other options:

The predominant lipid of:

  • Chylomicron is dietary triacylglycerol.
  • LDL is cholesterol
  • HDL is phospholipids.

questions.text: What is the reason for the pyruvic acidosis seen in thiamine deficiency?
questions.solution:
Pyruvic and lactic acidosis seen in thiamine deficiency is due to a decrease in the activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase.

Thiamine pyrophosphate is a co-factor of pyruvate dehydrogenase and is needed for the decarboxylation of pyruvate before it can be oxidised into acetyl CoA. In thiamine deficiency, pyruvate can't be converted to acetyl CoA and hence there is an accumulation of pyruvate with excess conversion into lactate.

Oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate:

Thiamine pyrophosphate also acts as a cofactor of alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, branched-chain keto-acid dehydrogenase, and transketolase enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the JVP deflection marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The deflection marked in the JVP waveform is the V wave which is due to venous filling of right atrium against a closed tricuspid valve.

Jugular venous pressure measured in the internal jugular vein is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. A normal waveform has the following deflections.

  • a wave: corresponds to Atrial contraction
  • c wave: corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction.
  • x descent: corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole
  • v wave: corresponds to the venous filling of the right atrium
  • y descent: passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the cogwheel rigidity seen in parkinsonism?
questions.solution:
Cog wheel rigidity is caused by tremor superimposed on hypertonia. Here, resistance to passive movement is reduced intermittently by the tremor and the movement resembles a cog wheel. It is seen with extrapyramidal tract involvement in conditions such as parkinsonism.

Clasp knife effect is seen in upper motor neuron lesions with spasticity. There is a sudden giving away after initial resistance to passive movement, like a folding clasp knife.

questions.text: The most pungent inhalation agent among the following is:
questions.solution:
The most pungent inhalation anaesthetic among the following is desflurane.

Desflurane and isoflurane are airway irritants causing cough, breath holding, salivation and may lead to laryngospasm. Hence, they are not used for inhalation induction.

questions.text: The characteristic site of tenderness in de Quervain’s disease is?
questions.solution:
The characteristic site of tenderness for de Quervain’s disease is tip of radial styloid.

The characteristic site of tenderness for other conditions:

  • Scaphoid fracture - anatomical snuffbox
  • Carpo-metacarpal osteoarthritis - base of first metacarpal
  • Kienbock’s disease - over the lunate

questions.text: Which of the following structures would be spared in a rupture of the perineal body?
questions.solution:
Coccygeus muscle would be spared in a rupture of the perineal body.

The coccygeus muscle is a muscle of the pelvic floor that originates at the pelvic surface of ischial spine and inserts on the lateral margin of the coccyx and border of the sacrum. Although near the perineal body, this muscle does not directly have any association with this structure and would likely be spared in a perineal body rupture.

The perineal body is located at the junction of the urogenital and anal triangles – the central point of the perineum.

It functions as a point of attachment for muscle fibres from the pelvic floor and perineum, which includes:

  1. Levator ani
  2. Bulbospongiosus muscle
  3. Superficial and deep transverse perineal
  4. External anal sphincter
  5. External urethral sphincter muscle fibres

Related Pearl: Perineal Body

The perineal body is not a structure but an aggregation of fibromuscular tissue located in the midline at the junction between the anal and urogenital triangles, just ventral to the anal sphincter.

Ten muscles of the perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body.

Category Muscles
Two unpaired
  • Fibres of longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal
  • Fibres from External anal sphincter
Four Paired
  • Bulbospongiosus
  • Superficial transverse perenei
  • Deep transverse perenei
  • Levator ani

Note: In females, sphincter urethrovaginalis is also attached here.

questions.text:
General facial features are preserved in which of the following?
i- Mummification, ii- Adipocere formation, iii- Putrefaction, iv- Livor mortis
questions.solution:
Facial features are well preserved in mummification, adipocere formation, and livor mortis/postmortem hypostasis. Hence, it is possible to establish the identity of the dead person in these conditions.

Facial features are not preserved in putrefaction because of marked gaseous swelling of face, eye balls and tongue.

questions.text: Todani classification system is used for the assessment of _______.
questions.solution:
Todani classification is used for the assessment of Choledochal cysts.

Other options:

Option C: Milwaukee classification is used to assess the sphincter of Oddi dysfunction.

Option D: Strasberg classification is used in bile duct injuries. It is based on the anatomical location of the injury.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: True regarding Type 4b Myocardial infarction:

choices.text: Death occurs before cardiac biomarkers can be evaluated.

questions.solution:
T4b myocardial infarction (MI) occurs due to associated stent thrombosis. Other options:

questions.text: Which of the following medication is unsafe in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Propranolol is a non-selective beta blocker and is not safe for use during pregnancy.

Antihypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors, ARBs
  • Diuretics
  • Nonselective beta blockers
  • Nitroprusside

Antihypertensives found to be safe in pregnancy:

  • Hydralazine
  • Methyldopa
  • Dihydropyridine CCBs: should be stopped before labor as they weaken the uterine contractions
  • Cardio-selective beta blockers and those with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity: may be used as a last choice

L-thyroxine is a Category A drug in pregnancy and thus is safe.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions, is due to the paternal disomy of chromosome 15?

questions.text: Which of the following is a third generation intra-uterine device (IUD)?
questions.solution:
Mirena is the only third generation intrauterine device (IUD) out of the given options.

  • First generation IUD – inert or non-medicated devices like Lippes loop.
  • Second generation IUD - medicated with metallic elements like Copper eg:  Cu-T-220 C, Nova T, Multi-load Cu-250, Multi-load Cu-375.
  • Third generation IUD – hormone containing IUD – progestasert, Mirena (LNG-20).

questions.text: The feature not found in Marfan syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Skeletal fragility is not seen in Marfan syndrome. It is a feature of osteogenesis imperfecta (type 1 collagen disease).

Marfan syndrome is caused by inherited defect in the extracellular glycoprotein fibrillin-1. It is an autosomal dominant disorder with mutations affecting FBN1 gene on chromosome 15.

Clinical features:

Skeletal abnormalities-

  • Slender, elongated habitus with abnormally long legs, arms, and fingers (arachnodactyly)
  • High arched palate, hyperextensibility of joints
  • Spinal deformities- such as severe kyphoscoliosis
  • Chest deformities- either pectus excavatum (i.e., deeply depressed sternum) or a pigeon chest deformity

Ocular changes- bilateral dislocation or subluxation of the lens secondary to weakness of its suspensory ligaments (ectopia lentis)

Cardiovascular abnormalities-

  • Cystic medionecrosis- Fragmentation of the elastic fibers in the tunica media of the aorta predisposes the patients to aneurysmal dilation and aortic dissection
  • Floppy valve syndrome- The cardiac valves, especially the mitral valve, may be excessively distensible and regurgitant giving rise to mitral valve prolapse and congestive cardiac failure
  • Aortic rupture is the most common cause of death

questions.text: Dark brown post mortem lividity is seen in:
questions.solution:
Dark brown post-mortem lividity is seen in phosphorous poisoning.

Post-mortem lividity is also known as Livor Mortis, postmortem hypostasis, postmortem staining, suggilations, and vibices. Usually, it is a reddish-purple discoloration due to the passive pooling of blood into the dependent areas of the body.

This color depends on the state of oxygenation at the time of death. Death due to hypoxia, results in darker colored skin due to reduced hemoglobin in the cutaneous vessels. However, if someone dies due to hypothermia (Option B), the color of the skin may be pink due to the presence of oxyhemoglobin. This happens because the tissues do not take up oxygen from the circulating blood due to reduced metabolism.

Other color changes include:

  • Cherry-pink color in carbon monoxide (Option D) or hydrocyanic acid (Option A) poisoning.
  • Chocolate/coffee-brown color in poisoning by potassium chlorate, potassium bichromate, nitrobenzene, or aniline.
  • Dark brown color in phosphorus poisoning.
  • A refrigerated dead body may show bright pink patches.

questions.text: In a normal curve, what is the percentage of distribution falls within two standard deviation of the mean?
questions.solution:
Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 standard deviations of the mean.

Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 standard deviations of the mean.

Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 standard deviations of the mean.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history suggestive of a transient ischemic attack 5 hours ago. Which of the following determines the risk for future stroke?
questions.solution:
The risk of stroke following TIAs is determined by the ABCD2 score.

TIA is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke-like symptoms) lasting for less than 24 hours. This occurs due to focal ischemia of the brain, retina, or cochlea. There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA. 

Other options:

Options B and C: BISAP (bedside index of severity in a/c pancreatitis) and APACHE II are used for assessing the severity of acute pancreatitis.

Option D: CHADS2 score determines the risk of stroke in atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient presents with bands of pruritic, flagellate, and erythematous lesions over the trunk and extremities. He is a known case of Hodgkin’s lymphoma and is on treatment with an ABVD regimen for the past 4 months. What is the drug responsible for the presenting features?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of flagellate dermatitis. It is a specific adverse effect of bleomycin.

Bleomycin is an anticancer antibiotic. It acts by generating free radicals by binding with a reducing agent (iron) in the presence of oxygen. This metal-drug complex cleaves the DNA of the tumor cell.

It is used as a component in the treatment regimens of Hodgkin's lymphoma and testicular cancer.

Bleomycin has a bone marrow–sparing effect. The major adverse events include flagellate dermatitis and pulmonary toxicity, which may progress to pulmonary fibrosis.

Flagellate dermatitis starts as bands of pruritic, flagellate, and erythematous lesions over the trunk and extremities. These rashes heal with persistent flagellate hyperpigmentation. No treatment is necessary since the lesions usually disappear on the stoppage of the drug. These lesions respond to topical corticosteroids.

The image given below shows flagellate dermatitis.

Other agents causing flagellate dermatitis are docetaxel, bendamustine, and peplomycin.

Other options:

Option A: Adriamycin/doxorubicin is an anthracycline antineoplastic drug. It is used for the treatment of malignant lymphomas, Ewing sarcoma, soft-tissue sarcomas, and breast carcinoma. The major adverse effects include myelosuppression, cardiomyopathy, alopecia, and stomatitis. 

Option C: Vinblastine is a vinca alkaloid. Adverse effects of vinblastine include leucopenia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and anorexia. Local reactions like cellulitis and phlebitis may occur on drug extravasation during the injection.

Option D: Dacarbazine is a methylating agent used in the treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma, malignant melanoma, and sarcomas. The adverse effects include myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, flu-like syndrome, and alopecia.

Related Pearl: Lobes involved in various lung diseases

questions.text: In the three swab test done for genitourinary fistula, what does staining of only the middle swab with dye indicate?
questions.solution:
Staining of only the middle swab with dye indicates vesicovaginal fistula.

The methylene dye 3 swab test is done to differentiate between ureterovaginal, vesicovaginal and urethrovaginal fistulas. It is done as follows:

  • Three cotton swabs are placed in the vagina – one at the vault, one at the middle and one just above the introitus
  • Methylene blue is instilled into the bladder through a rubber catheter and the patient is asked to walk for 5 minutes
  • The swabs are then examined
Finding Inference
Only uppermost swab wet but not stained with dye Ureterovaginal fistula
Only middle swab stained with dye Vesicovaginal fistula
Only lowermost swab stained with dye Urethrovaginal fistula

questions.text: Important landmark in dissection of deep lobe of submandibular gland is:
questions.solution:
An important landmark in submandibular gland dissection is the posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle.

Once identified, it can be retracted forwards to reveal the deep lobe of the gland.The hypoglossal nerves lie deep to the submandibular capsule and should not be damaged during intracapsular dissection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of pancreatic cancer?

questions.text: The Ujjwala yojana is for:

choices.text: Providing LPG connections to families below the poverty line
Improving the quality of labour rooms
Providing home based born care by ASHA

questions.solution:
The Ujjwala Yojana (note spelling without "a") is for providing 5 crore free cooking (LPG) connections to all families below the poverty line till 2019.

The Ujjawala Scheme is for prevention of trafficking and for rescue, rehabilitation and reintegration of victims of trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation.

The LAQSHYA initiative is for improving the quality of labour rooms and providing Respectful Maternity Care. It also includes expanding the obstetric ICUs at government medical college hospitals.

questions.text: Which of the following factors does not play a role in the termination of acute inflammatory response is?
questions.solution:
Interleukin 6 does not play a role in the termination of acute inflammatory response as it is a pro-inflammatory cytokine.

Factors that contribute to the termination of acute inflammatory response:

  • Anti-inflammatory cytokines- IL-10 and TGF-β.
  • Neutrophils have short half-lives in tissues and die by apoptosis within hours to a day or two after leaving the blood. 
  • Mediators of inflammation are produced in rapid bursts and have short half-lives.

  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production

questions.text: Beta haemolytic streptococci are classified based on:
questions.solution:
Lancefield grouping of streptococci is based on group-specific carbohydrate antigen.

  • Beta-haemolytic streptococci were classified by Lancefield based on group-specific carbohydrate C antigen present on the cell wall, into 20 serological types from Group A to Group V except for I and J.
  • Group A beta-haemolytic streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes) are further classified based on protein (M, T, and R) antigens present on the cell surface by Griffith typing.
