questions.text: A midline cleft lip is due to the failure of fusion between:
questions.solution:
Median or midline cleft lip is caused by incomplete merging of two medial nasal prominences in midline.

Cleft lip usually occurs when the maxillary prominences fail to fuse with the medial nasal prominences and when the underlying somitomeric mesoderm and neural crest fail to proliferate, resulting in a persistent labial groove.

In a unilateral cleft lip, the nasal septum deviates to the non-cleft side. This is because the muscles on the medial side of the cleft (transverse muscles of the nose and orbicularis oris) are not inserted into either the muscles of the contralateral side or the tissues around the nasal septum.

Related Pearl: Timing of primary cleft lip and palate procedures:

Cleft lip alone

  • Unilateral (one side) - One operation at 3–6 months
  • Bilateral (both sides) - One operation at 4–5 months

Cleft palate alone

  • Soft palate - Only one operation at 6 months
  • Soft and hard palate - Two operations
    • Soft palate at 6 months
    • Hard palate at 15–18 months

Cleft lip and palate

  • Unilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 5–6 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months
  • Bilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 4–5 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months

Secondary management

  • Hearing, Prophylactic myringotomy, Regular audiological testing - 6–12 months

  • Speech, Velopharyngeal surgery, Speech and language therapy - 18 months

  • Orthodontic management

    - Mixed dentition - 8–10 years
    - Permanent dentition - 14-18 years

  • Excision of maxillary arch, Rhinoplasty - 16+ years

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of Paget’s disease?
questions.solution:
Serum phosphate levels are normal in Paget’s disease.

Complications seen in Paget’s disease:

  • Fractures- Fractures are common, especially in the weight-bearing long bones.
  • Nerve compression and spinal stenosis- Cranial nerve compression may lead to impaired vision, facial palsy, trigeminal neuralgia or deafness.
  • Bone sarcoma- Osteosarcoma arising in an elderly patient is almost always due to malignant transformation in Paget’s disease. The frequency of malignant change is around 1 per cent.

questions.text: Which of the following endocrine abnormality causes chronic symmetric gait ataxia?
questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is a readily treatable and reversible cause of chronic gait ataxia.

Causes of chronic gait ataxia:

  • Antigliadin antibody syndrome
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Inherited diseases
  • Tabes dorsalis (tertiary syphilis)
  • Phenytoin toxicity
  • Amiodarone

questions.text: In pseudo Foster-Kennedy syndrome with papilledema of the left eye, which of the following findings is seen in the other eye?
questions.solution:
In pseudo Foster-Kennedy syndrome, there is papilledema in one eye and optic atrophy in the other. It differs from Foster-Kennedy syndrome in that the optic atrophy is pre-existent and not caused by pressure from an intracranial mass.

Related Pearl: Foster–Kennedy Syndrome

  • It is characterized by the occurrence of:
    • Ipsilateral pressure optic atrophy and
    • Contralateral papilledema (due to raised intracranial pressure).
  • It is associated with olfactory or sphenoidal meningiomata and frontal lobe tumors.

Pseudo-Foster–Kennedy syndrome: It is characterized by the occurrence of:

  • Pre-existing optic atrophy due to any cause on one eye.
  • Unilateral papilledema associated with raised intracranial pressure due to some other cause on the opposite side.

Osteogenesis imperfecta is an autosomal dominant disorder.

Color blindness is an X-linked recessive disorder.

Sickle cell anemia and Cystic fibrosis are autosomal recessive disorders.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with headache for the past 4 months, she was treated with radiotherapy for vestibular schwannoma 2 year back. What is the probable diagnosis we can arrive from the contrast MRI shown below?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of the above patient is meningioma.

The well-defined, hyper intense and homogeneously enhanced mass close to the midline, situated extra-axially (i.e., outside the brain parenchyma). Being non-glial in origin they arise from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges, and thus can occur anywhere meninges are found.

Meningomas are associated with:

  • Female predominance (some meningiomas contain estrogen and progesterone receptors).
  • Genetic preponderance: Genetic mutations associated with meningioma are NF-2 and MEN1 mutations.
  • Ionizing radiation

Useful descriptive signs on MRI are:

  • CSF vascular cleft sign helps to establish that mass to be extra-axial. There is a cleft between tumor and normal brain parenchyma.
  • Dural tail sign: Refers to the linear extension of enhancement the dura, beyond the segment on which the tumor is based.
  • Sunburst or spoke wheel appearance of the vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following factors do not contribute to skin colour?
questions.solution:
The number of melanocytes does not contribute to the pigmentation of the skin. There is very little inter-racial variation in the number of melanocytes.

Variation in skin pigmentation is explained by:

  • Differences in melanocyte structure and function
  • Melanogenic activity i.e the amount of melanin produced
  • Size and number of melanosomes
  • Type of melanin deposited onto melanosomes
  • Donation of mature melanosomes to adjacent keratinocytes

Related Pearl: Colour of Skin and Fitzpatrick Classification of Skin types

  • The color of the skin is a property of the pigment melanin synthesized by melanocytes.
  • Melanocytes are dendritic cells derived from neural crest cells and are present in the stratum basale of the epidermis.
  • Each melanocyte synthesizes melanin and packs it in cell organelles to form melanosomes. These melanosomes are transferred through dendritic processes to 36 keratinocytes forming the epidermal melanin unit.
  • The main function of melanin is to impart uniform color to the skin. It also protects cells from UV light.
  • Color of skin depends on the following:
    • Amount of melanin inside melanocytes
    • Number and size of melanosomes
    • Degree of transfer of melanin into keratinocytes
  • It does NOT depend on the number of melanocytes. This is because all individuals contain the same number of melanocytes /cm2 of skin area.

Different shades of skin color in humans is due to 2 factors:

  • Difference in number, size, and distribution of melanosomes.
  • Difference in proportion of eumelanin and pheomelanin. 
Eumelanin Pheomelanin
True melanin False melanin
Brown or black pigment Yellow-red pigment
Present in dark-skinned individuals Present in fair-skinned individuals

The different shades have been classified in the Fitzpatrick classification of skin type scale. It is based on tan ability and burn ability of the skin.

Type 1 Type 6
Excess pheomelanin Excess eumelanin
Always burns Never burns
Never tans Always tans
Maximum malignant Potential Least malignant potential

questions.text: Activated charcoal is a:
questions.solution:
Activated charcoal acts as a mechanical antidote.

Mechanical antidotes- They neutralise poisons by mechanical action or prevention of their absorption.

  • Activated charcoal- It acts mechanically by adsorbing and retaining organic and mineral poisons within its pores and thus delays the absorption from the stomach.
  • Demulcents- substances that coat the gastric mucous membrane and thus do not permit the poisons to    cause any damage, e.g. milk, starch, egg-white, mineral oil, milk of magnesia, aluminium hydroxide gel, etc
  • Bulky food is the mechanical antidote to glass powder, wherein it acts by imprisoning its particles within its meshes.

Chemical antidotes- They neutralise poison by forming harmless or insoluble compounds or by oxidation when it is brought in contact with them.

  • Common salt decomposes silver nitrate, forming the insoluble silver chloride.
  • Potassium permanganate has oxidising properties. 1:5000 solution is used in opium poisoning.

Chelating agents (metal complexing agents) are used in the treatment of heavy metal poisoning. The metal-agent complex is more water-soluble than the metal itself, resulting in higher renal excretion of the complex.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with nutritional melalgia?
questions.solution:
Pantothenic acid/ Vitamin B5 deficiency leads to burning feet syndrome, also known as nutritional melalgia or Gopalan's syndrome.

It acts as a functional part of CoA or acyl carrier protein. CoA plays a role in fatty acid oxidation, the citric acid cycle, acetylations, and cholesterol synthesis. ACP is involved in the fatty acid synthesis.

Deficiency leads to peripheral nerve damage leading to burning foot syndrome. It is mostly seen during a famine, in prison camps, in chronic alcoholics, and in renal dialysis patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding a stable atherosclerotic plaque?
questions.solution:
A stable atherosclerotic plaque has abundant smooth muscle cells.

These cells synthesize collagen which stabilizes the plaque. Both these features contribute to a thick fibrous cap that prevents the easy rupture of a plaque.

Stable plaque Vulnerable plaque
Dense collagen Less collagen
Thick fibrous cap Thin fibrous cap
Minimal inflammation Increased inflammation
Less extracellular lipid Abundant extracellular lipid
Abundant smooth muscle cells Few smooth muscle cells
Few foam cells Abundant  foam cells

questions.text: Which of the following treats fracture by primary bone healing?
questions.solution:
Fractures fixed rigidly with plates rely on primary bone healing.

Fractures treated with intramedullary nails, bridge plates, and many external fixators rely upon secondary bone healing.

Healing is similar to the remodeling phase of secondary bone healing, with osteoclasts converting woven bone to lamellar bone.

Relative stability is provided by these devices when attempting to obtain secondary bone healing. These fractures heal with callus formation and progress through stages: (1) inflammatory stage, (2) soft callus stage, (3) hard callus stage, and (4) remodeling phase.

questions.text: Which of the following can be considered as criteria for initiating dialysis?

choices.text: GFR < 20 ml/min/1.73m2 with the presence of bleeding diathesis

questions.solution:
Initiating patients on maintenance dialysis can be done when there is: 

  • Presence of uremic symptoms
  • Presence of hyperkalemia unresponsive to conservative measures
  • Persistent extra- cellular volume expansion despite diuretic therapy
  • Acidosis refractory to medical therapy
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Estimated glomerular filtration rate (GFR) <10 mL/min per 1.73m2

It is noted that there is no benefit to initiating dialysis pre-emptively at a GFR of 10-14 mL/min/1.73m2 compared to initiating dialysis in the presence of uremic symptoms.

questions.text: What is the primary source of ATP in fast and fatigable muscle fibres?
questions.solution:
Glycolysis is the primary source of ATP in fast and fatigable muscle fibres as their oxidative capacity is low. The eventual build-up of lactate generated during the process of anaerobic glycolysis leads to fatigue.

questions.text: The epidermal layer that is absent in psoriatic skin lesions is
questions.solution:
Stratum granulosum is absent in the psoriatic lesions.

Histopathological features of psoriatic plaques:

  • Hyperproliferation of the basal layer
  • Rapid progression of basal keratinocytes through the epidermal layers (4–5 days in the active plaques)
  • Decreased differentiation of keratinocytes
  • Elongated rete ridges (camel foot appearance)
  • Acanthosis
  • Absence of the granular layer

questions.text: The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ includes:
questions.solution:
The components of the Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) for grading ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) are as follows:

  • Patient’s age
  • Type of DCIS (histologic variant based on nuclear grade and presence of necrosis)
  • Presence of microcalcification
  • Extent of resection margin
  • Size of tumor

Staining for estrogen and progesterone receptors is not a part of the Van Nuys system.

Patients with a high score in this grading system benefit from radiotherapy after excision, whereas those with low-grade tumors, whose tumor is completely excised, need no further treatment.

A score, ranging from 1 for lesions with the best prognosis to 3 for lesions with the worst prognosis, is given for each of the four prognostic predictors.  Scores range from 4 (least likely to recur) to 12 (most likely to recur).

Parameter Score 1 Score 2 Score 3
Tumor size (diameter in mm) < 15 16–40 greater or equal to 41
Margin width (in mm) >10 1–9 < 1
Pathologic Classification non-high grade, (nuclear grades 1 and 2) no necrosis non-high grade, (nuclear grades 1 and 2)with necrosis high grade (nuclear grade 3) with or without necrosis
Age  >60 40–60 <40

Note: The type of microcalcification seen on imaging, helps in determining the nuclear grade of DCIS.

  • Linear branching type of microcalcification is associated with high nuclear grade.
  • Fine granular type of microcalcification is associated with low nuclear grade.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Burkitt’s Lymphoma?

choices.text: It is an intermediate grade NHL
It is the most common type of NHL

questions.solution:
Burkitt lymphoma is a fast-growing type of high-grade non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). Pediatric NHLs are high grade and aggressive. 

The International Working Group classifies NHLs on the basis of their morphology and clinical behaviour. This classification is not currently used but has been tested in past examination (Rappaport Classification).

Low grade

  • Small lymphocytic/chronic lymphocytic leukaemia
  • Follicular, predominantly small cleaved cell
  • Follicular, mixed (small cleaved and large cell)

Intermediate grade

  • Follicular, predominantly large cell
  • Diffuse, small cleaved cell
  • Diffuse, mixed small and large cell
  • Diffuse, large cell

High grade

  • Large cell, immunoblastic
  • Lymphoma, lymphoblastic
  • Small noncleaved cells (Burkitt's lymphoma)

A simplified summary of the clinical behaviour of NHL is:

  • Low grade: CLL/SLL, follicular lymphoma
  • Intermediate grade: Mantle cell and marginal cell lymphoma
  • High grade: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), Burkitt's lymphoma

Note:

  • DLBCL is the most common type of NHL.  
  • The most rapidly progressive human tumour is Burkitt's lymphoma
  • Pediatric NHLs are high grade and aggressive

questions.text: A patient presents with right lower abdominal pain and loose stools for the past 8 months. He smokes 12 cigarettes per day for the last 10 years. Endoscopy findings are shown below. Smoking increases the relative risk of which among the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of loose stools, right lower quadrant pain and endoscopy showing cobblestone appearance, with a history of smoking suggest a diagnosis of Crohn's disease (CD) and smoking increases the relative risk of Crohn's disease.

The risk is increased threefold times with smoking. The cessation of smoking has a beneficial effect on the disease activity. 

Features include

  • Non-caseating granulomas on the layers of the small bowel, lymph nodes, mesentery, peritoneum, liver, and pancreas.
  • Submucosal or subserosal lymphoid aggregates, microscopic skip areas, transmural inflammation, etc are also seen.
  • Inflammation of the ileum and colon, with rectal sparing.
  • Aphthous ulcers in early stages and later spreads to result in transmural inflammation.
  • Skip lesions are seen in microscopy. There is normal mucosa in between the ulcers which gives them a cobblestone appearance.
  • Creeping fat is the growth of mesenteric fat leading to extensive fat wrapping around the bowel wall.

In ulcerative colitis, smoking has a protective effect (option A).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of strychnine poisoning?
questions.solution:
Carphologia is not a feature of strychnine poisoning.

Carphologia - picking at the bedding/clothing, trying to pull imaginary threads from tips of fingers, threading imaginary needle etc. It is a feature of datura poisoning.

Risus sardonicus - The contraction of muscles of the face causing the angles of the mouth to be drawn wide apart with creases appearing in and around the eyelids.

Opisthotonos - Arching of the body in hyperextension because of spasm of anti-gravity muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following is a hallmark feature of malignancy?
questions.solution:
Anaplasia is a hallmark of malignancy.

Anaplasia refers to the lack of differentiation of cells i.e, the neoplastic parenchymal cells do not resemble/poorly resemble the corresponding normal parenchymal cells functionally and morphologically.

The other most reliable indicators of malignancy are metastasis and invasiveness of the tumour.

Other options:

Dysplasia refers to disordered growth. It is encountered principally in epithelia and is characterized by loss in the uniformity of the individual cells and a loss in their architectural orientation. Dysplasia may be a precursor to malignant transformation but it does not always progress to cancer.

Mitotic cells are also seen in normal tissues exhibiting rapid turnover, such as the epithelial lining of the gut and non-neoplastic proliferations such as hyperplasias.

Nuclear-to-cytoplasm ratio of 1:4 or 1:6 is considered normal. This ratio may approach 1:1 in malignant cells.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions shows ring of fire pattern on transvaginal colour doppler scanning?
questions.solution:
Ring of fire pattern is seen on transvaginal colour doppler in tubal pregnancy. The appearance is due to placental blood flow within the periphery of the complex adnexal mass. This finding is also seen with corpus luteum cysts, although the wall is less echogenic compared to a tubal ectopic.

Ring of fire appearance on colour doppler:

questions.text: Acute graft rejection is mediated by:
questions.solution:
Acute graft rejection is mediated by the T cells of the host.

Graft rejection is the process by which T lymphocytes and antibodies destroy tissue grafts. It can be classified into:

  • Hyperacute rejection: mediated by preformed antibodies that are specific for the antigens on the graft. 
  • Acute rejection can be divided into:
    • Acute cellular rejection is mediated by T cells. It causes direct damage to graft cells via CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes or causes indirect damage to the graft cells by CD4+ cells which secrete cytokines and induce inflammation.
    • Acute antibody-mediated rejection is mediated by antibodies that are produced after coming in contact with graft antigens. These antibodies bind to the graft vascular endothelium and activate the complement system causing graft failure.
  • Chronic rejection: slowly occurring damage to the graft that is caused by interstitial fibrosis and narrowing of graft blood vessels - graft arteriosclerosis.

 Other options:

Option B & D: Donor CD8+ and CD4+ T cells are implicated in graft-versus-host disease. Graft-versus-host disease is usually seen in hematopoeitic stem cell transplantation and occurs due to immunologically competent cells of the graft recognizing the recipient's HLA antigens as foreign and attacking them. In most conditions, this can be prevented by irradiating or treating the recipient with high doses of chemotherapy to destroy the immune system

Option C: As mentioned above, preformed antibodies mediate hyperacute graft rejection. Preformed antibodies are antibodies that are previously produced. They can be natural IgM antibodies to blood group antigens or antibodies to allogeneic major histocompatibility molecules that were induced by prior exposure (through blood transfusion, pregnancy, etc).

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

  • Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas
    • Neutrophils accumulate
    • Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

  1. Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  
    • Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
      • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
  2. Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 
    • Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.
      • Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.
      • Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

  • Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)
    • Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane
    • Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

questions.text: Damage to the axillary nerve would affect the function of which of the following rotator cuff muscles?
questions.solution:
The teres minor is the only rotator cuff muscle innervated by the axillary nerve, and thus its ability to function would be affected if the axillary nerve is damaged.

Rotator cuff muscles:

The rotator cuff is a group of 4 muscles (SITS) that stabilizes the shoulder joint:

Muscle Insertion Innervation
S: Supraspinatus Greater tubercle Suprascapular nerve
I: Infraspinatus Greater tubercle Suprascapular nerve 
T: Teres Minor Greater tubercle Axillary nerve
S: Subscapularis Lesser tubercle Upper and Lower subscapular nerve 

 

Clinical correlate: 

Shoulder impingement syndrome, also called subacromial impingement, painful arc syndrome, supraspinatus syndrome, swimmer's shoulder is a clinical syndrome which occurs when the tendons of the rotator cuff muscles become irritated and inflamed as they pass through the subacromial space.

questions.text: Identify the function of the vasa recta in the kidney:
questions.solution:
The vasa recta maintain medullary osmotic gradient by minimising the washout of solutes from the medullary interstitium. These vessels are U shaped and act as counter-current exchangers.  In the descending limb of the vessel, water is lost to the interstitium whereas solutes are absorbed into the bloodstream. This process is reversed in the ascending limb and as a result, there is little change in solute concentration in the medullary interstitium.

Other options:

The loop of Henle acts as a counter-current multiplier and creates the medullary osmotic gradient.

questions.text: A patient comes to the hospital with history of sudden and brief loss of consciousness. During this episode he had no loss of postural control. Also, there was no post-ictal confusion. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation the diagnosis is absence seizures.

It is characterized by sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control that lasts only few seconds. However, there is no post ictal confusion.

EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and the seizures.

Other options:

  • Atonic seizures are characterized by sudden loss of postural control.
  • Myoclonic seizures have preserved consciousness.
  • Generalized tonic clonic seizures are characterized by post ictal confusion.

questions.text: Identify the mechanism of action of transcranial magnetic stimulation:
questions.solution:
Transcranial magnetic stimulation works by inducing eddy currents in the brain cortex by the application of rapidly changing magnetic fields. The currents induced bring about neuronal stimulation.

It is approved as a monotherapy for the treatment of resistant depression. It can also be used with antipsychotics in the treatment of resistant schizophrenia.

Other options:

The left vagal nerve is intermittently stimulated in vagal nerve stimulation therapy and is indicated as adjunctive therapy in resistant depression.

Related Pearl: ECT versus TMS

  Electroconvulsive Therapy Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation
Principle Seizures are induced by applying an electric current Induction of eddy currents in the cortex by applying magnetic fields
Mechanism Neuroplasticity; induced seizures promote new synapse formation Neuronal stimulation by eddy currents
Advantages
  • More effective
  • Faster response
  • Shorter treatment course
  • Non-invasive
  • Enables focal stimulation of cortical areas
  • No significant memory loss
  • Does not induce seizures
Disadvantages
  • Invasive
  • Requires anesthesia
  • Significant cognitive impairment
  • Less effective
  • Slower response
  • Prolonged treatment course
